   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">

   </h1>

    </div>

        </a>

     <p>
      <b>
       Michael Joseph Jackson
      </b>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-2">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        2
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      (August 29, 1958  June 25, 2009) was an American singer, songwriter, record producer, dancer, and actor. Called the
      <a href="/wiki/Honorific_nicknames_in_popular_music" title="Honorific nicknames in popular music">
       King of Pop
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LJ3_4-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-LJ3-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arar_5-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Arar-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SBee_6-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SBee-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      his contributions to music and dance, along with his publicized personal life, made him a global figure in popular culture for over four decades.
     </p>
     <p>
      The eighth child of the
      <a href="/wiki/Jackson_family" title="Jackson family">
       Jackson family
      </a>
      , he debuted on the professional music scene along with his elder brothers
      <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Jackson" title="Jackie Jackson">
       Jackie
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tito_Jackson" title="Tito Jackson">
       Tito
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">
       Jermaine
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Jackson" title="Marlon Jackson">
       Marlon
      </a>
      as a member of
      <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">
       the Jackson 5
      </a>
      in 1964, and began his solo career in 1971. In the early 1980s, Jackson became a dominant figure in
      <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">
       popular music
      </a>
      . The music videos for his songs, including those of "
      <a href="/wiki/Beat_It" title="Beat It">
       Beat It
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean" title="Billie Jean">
       Billie Jean
      </a>
      ", and "
      <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(song)" title="Thriller (song)">
       Thriller
      </a>
      ", were credited with breaking down racial barriers and with transforming the medium into an art form and promotional tool. The popularity of these videos helped to bring the then-relatively-new television channel
      <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">
       MTV
      </a>
      to fame. With videos such as "
      <a href="/wiki/Black_or_White" title="Black or White">
       Black or White
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Scream/Childhood" title="Scream/Childhood">
       Scream
      </a>
      ", he continued to innovate the medium throughout the 1990s, as well as forging a reputation as a touring solo artist. Through stage and video performances, Jackson popularized a number of complicated dance techniques, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Robot_(dance)" title="Robot (dance)">
       robot
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(dance)" title="Moonwalk (dance)">
       moonwalk
      </a>
      , to which he gave the name. His distinctive sound and style has influenced numerous artists of various music genres.
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson's 1982 album
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Thriller (Michael Jackson album)">
        Thriller
       </a>
      </i>
      is the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_albums" title="List of best-selling albums">
       best-selling album of all time
      </a>
      . His other albums, including
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall_(album)" title="Off the Wall (album)">
        Off the Wall
       </a>
      </i>
      (1979),
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Bad_(album)" title="Bad (album)">
        Bad
       </a>
      </i>
      (1987),
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Dangerous_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)">
        Dangerous
       </a>
      </i>
      (1991), and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/HIStory:_Past,_Present_and_Future,_Book_I" title="HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I">
        HIStory
       </a>
      </i>
      (1995), also rank among the world's best-selling albums. Jackson is one of the few artists to have been inducted into the
      <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">
       Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
      </a>
      twice. He was also inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame and the Dance Hall of Fame as the first and only dancer from pop and rock music. His other
      <a href="/wiki/Records_and_achievements_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Records and achievements of Michael Jackson">
       achievements
      </a>
      include multiple
      <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">
       Guinness World Records
      </a>
      , 13
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">
       Grammy Awards
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Legend_Award" title="Grammy Legend Award">
       Grammy Legend Award
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award" title="Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award">
       Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award
      </a>
      , 26
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Music_Awards" title="American Music Awards">
       American Music Awards
      </a>
      more than any other artistincluding the "Artist of the Century" and "Artist of the 1980s", 13
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_artists_by_number_of_Billboard_Hot_100_number-one_singles" title="List of artists by number of Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles">
       number-one singles in the United States
      </a>
      during his solo career,more than any other male artist in the
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">
       Hot 100
      </a>
      eraand estimated sales of over 400 million records worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="ref_Note_1">
       <a href="#endnote_Note_1">
        [Note 1]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson has won
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Michael_Jackson" title="List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson">
       hundreds of awards
      </a>
      , making him the most awarded recording artist in the history of popular music.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-7">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        7
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He became the first artist in history to have a top ten single in the
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">
       <i>
        Billboard
       </i>
       Hot 100
      </a>
      in five different decades when "
      <a href="/wiki/Love_Never_Felt_So_Good" title="Love Never Felt So Good">
       Love Never Felt So Good
      </a>
      " reached number nine on May 21, 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson traveled the world attending events honoring his humanitarianism, and, in 2000, the
      <i>
       Guinness World Records
      </i>
      recognized him for supporting 39 charities, more than any other entertainer.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Aspects of Michael Jackson's personal life, including his changing
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_health_and_appearance" title="Michael Jackson's health and appearance">
       appearance
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Personal_relationships_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Personal relationships of Michael Jackson">
       personal relationships
      </a>
      , and behavior, generated controversy. In the mid-1990s, he was
      <a href="/wiki/1993_child_sexual_abuse_accusations_against_Michael_Jackson" title="1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson">
       accused of child sexual abuse
      </a>
      , but the civil case was settled out of court for an undisclosed amount and no formal charges were brought.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-10">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        10
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2005, he was
      <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">
       tried and acquitted
      </a>
      of further child sexual abuse allegations and several other charges after the jury found him not guilty on all counts. While preparing for his comeback concert series titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(concerts)" title="This Is It (concerts)">
        This Is It
       </a>
      </i>
      , Jackson
      <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Death of Michael Jackson">
       died
      </a>
      of acute
      <a href="/wiki/Propofol" title="Propofol">
       propofol
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Benzodiazepine" title="Benzodiazepine">
       benzodiazepine
      </a>
      intoxication on June 25, 2009, after suffering from cardiac arrest. The
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_County_Department_of_Medical_Examiner-Coroner" title="Los Angeles County Department of Medical Examiner-Coroner">
       Los Angeles County Coroner
      </a>
      ruled his death a homicide, and his personal physician
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trial_of_Conrad_Murray" title="Trial of Conrad Murray">
       Conrad Murray was convicted
      </a>
      of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Involuntary_manslaughter" title="Involuntary manslaughter">
       involuntary manslaughter
      </a>
      . Jackson's death triggered a global outpouring of grief and a live broadcast of his
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_memorial_service" title="Michael Jackson memorial service">
       public memorial service
      </a>
      was viewed around the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Life_and_career">
       Life and career
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1958.E2.80.9375:_Early_life_and_the_Jackson_5">
       195875: Early life and the Jackson 5
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg">
        <img alt="The single-storey house has white walls, two windows, a central white door with a black door frame, and a black roof. In front of the house there is a walk way and multiple colored flowers and memorabilia." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3456" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg/220px-2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg/330px-2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg/440px-2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2300_Jackson_Street_Yuksel.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson's childhood home in
        <a href="/wiki/Gary,_Indiana" title="Gary, Indiana">
         Gary, Indiana
        </a>
        , showing floral tributes after his death.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Michael Joseph Jackson was born on August 29, 1958. He was the eighth of ten children in an African-American working-class family who lived in a two-bedroom house in
      <a href="/wiki/Gary,_Indiana" title="Gary, Indiana">
       Gary, Indiana
      </a>
      , an industrial city and a part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">
       Chicago metropolitan area
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His mother,
      <a href="/wiki/Katherine_Jackson" title="Katherine Jackson">
       Katherine Esther Scruse
      </a>
      , was a devout
      <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
       Jehovah's Witness
      </a>
      . She once aspired to be a country and western performer who played clarinet and piano, but worked part-time at
      <a href="/wiki/Sears" title="Sears">
       Sears
      </a>
      to help support the family.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His father,
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Jackson_(manager)" title="Joe Jackson (manager)">
       Joseph Walter "Joe" Jackson
      </a>
      , a former boxer, was a steelworker at
      <a href="/wiki/U.S._Steel" title="U.S. Steel">
       U.S. Steel
      </a>
      . Joe also performed on guitar with a local rhythm and blues band called the Falcons to supplement the family's household income.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        15
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Michael grew up with three sisters (
      <a href="/wiki/Rebbie_Jackson" title="Rebbie Jackson">
       Rebbie
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/La_Toya_Jackson" title="La Toya Jackson">
       La Toya
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">
       Janet
      </a>
      ) and five brothers (
      <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Jackson" title="Jackie Jackson">
       Jackie
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tito_Jackson" title="Tito Jackson">
       Tito
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">
       Jermaine
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Jackson" title="Marlon Jackson">
       Marlon
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Randy_Jackson_(The_Jacksons)" title="Randy Jackson (The Jacksons)">
       Randy
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G20_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G20-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A sixth brother, Marlon's elder twin Brandon, died shortly after birth.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
       <a href="#cite_note-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson had a troubled relationship with his father, Joe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secret_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Secret-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
       <a href="#cite_note-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2003, Joe acknowledged that he regularly whipped Jackson as a boy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        20
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Joe was also said to have verbally abused his son, often saying that he had a "fat nose".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        21
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson stated that he was physically and emotionally abused during incessant rehearsals, though he also credited his father's strict discipline with playing a large role in his success.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Secret_18-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Secret-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Speaking openly about his childhood in an interview with
      <a href="/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey" title="Oprah Winfrey">
       Oprah Winfrey
      </a>
      , broadcast in February 1993, Jackson acknowledged that his youth had been lonely and isolating.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's deep dissatisfaction with his appearance, his nightmares and chronic sleep problems, his tendency to remain hyper-compliant, especially with his father, and to remain childlike throughout his adult life, are consistent with the effects of the maltreatment he endured as a young child.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In an interview with
      <a href="/wiki/Martin_Bashir" title="Martin Bashir">
       Martin Bashir
      </a>
      , later included in the 2003 broadcast of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Living_with_Michael_Jackson" title="Living with Michael Jackson">
        Living with Michael Jackson
       </a>
      </i>
      , Jackson acknowledged that his father hurt him when he was a child, recalling that Joseph often sat in a chair with a belt in his hand as he and his siblings rehearsed, and that "if you didn't do it the right way, he would tear you up, really get you."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        24
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LJ1658_25-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-LJ1658-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Both of Jackson's parents have disagreed with the longstanding allegations of abuse, with Katherine stating that while the whippings are considered abuse today, such action was a common way to discipline children back then.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackie, Tito, Jermaine and Marlon have also said that their father is not abusive, but rather misunderstood.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="691" data-file-width="890" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG/220px-Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG/330px-Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG/440px-Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jackson_5_tv_special_1972.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson (center) as a member of the Jackson 5 in 1972.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1965, Michael and Marlon joined the Jackson Brothersa band formed by their father and which included brothers Jackie, Tito, and Jermaineas backup musicians playing
      <a href="/wiki/Conga" title="Conga">
       congas
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tambourine" title="Tambourine">
       tambourine
      </a>
      . In 1966, Jackson began sharing lead vocals with his older brother Jermaine, and the group's name was changed to
      <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">
       the Jackson 5
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G20_16-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G20-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      That following year, the group won a major local talent show with Jackson performing
      <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">
       James Brown
      </a>
      's "
      <a href="/wiki/I_Got_You_(I_Feel_Good)" title="I Got You (I Feel Good)">
       I Got You (I Feel Good)
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RRHF_30-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RRHF-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      From 1966 to 1968 the band toured the
      <a href="/wiki/Midwestern_United_States" title="Midwestern United States">
       Midwest
      </a>
      , frequently performing at a string of black clubs known as the "
      <a href="/wiki/Chitlin%27_circuit" title="Chitlin' circuit">
       chitlin' circuit
      </a>
      " as the opening act for artists such as
      <a href="/wiki/Sam_%26_Dave" title="Sam &amp; Dave">
       Sam &amp; Dave
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/The_O%27Jays" title="The O'Jays">
       the O'Jays
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Gladys_Knight" title="Gladys Knight">
       Gladys Knight
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Etta_James" title="Etta James">
       Etta James
      </a>
      . The Jackson 5 also performed at clubs and cocktail lounges, where
      <a href="/wiki/Striptease" title="Striptease">
       striptease
      </a>
      shows and other adult acts were featured, and at local auditoriums and high school dances.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In August 1967, while touring the
      <a href="/wiki/Eastern_United_States" title="Eastern United States">
       East
      </a>
      coast, the group won a weekly amateur night concert at the
      <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Theater" title="Apollo Theater">
       Apollo Theater
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">
       Harlem
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Jackson 5 recorded several songs, including "
      <a href="/wiki/Big_Boy_(song)" title="Big Boy (song)">
       Big Boy
      </a>
      " (1968), their first single, for
      <a href="/wiki/Steeltown_Records" title="Steeltown Records">
       Steeltown Records
      </a>
      , a Gary, Indiana, record label,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      before signing with
      <a href="/wiki/Motown" title="Motown">
       Motown
      </a>
      in 1969.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G20_16-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G20-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Jackson 5 left Gary in 1969 and relocated to the Los Angeles area, where they continued to record music for Motown.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        35
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The magazine
      <i>
       Rolling Stone
      </i>
      later described the young Michael as "a prodigy" with "overwhelming musical gifts," writing that he "quickly emerged as the main draw and lead singer."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio_36-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bio-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The group set a chart record when its first four singles"
      <a href="/wiki/I_Want_You_Back" title="I Want You Back">
       I Want You Back
      </a>
      " (1969), "
      <a href="/wiki/ABC_(The_Jackson_5_song)" title="ABC (The Jackson 5 song)">
       ABC
      </a>
      " (1970), "
      <a href="/wiki/The_Love_You_Save" title="The Love You Save">
       The Love You Save
      </a>
      " (1970), and "
      <a href="/wiki/I%27ll_Be_There_(The_Jackson_5_song)" title="I'll Be There (The Jackson 5 song)">
       I'll Be There
      </a>
      " (1970)peaked at number one on the
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">
       <i>
        Billboard
       </i>
       Hot 100
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G20_16-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-G20-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In May 1971, the Jackson family moved into a large home on two-acre estate in
      <a href="/wiki/Encino,_Los_Angeles" title="Encino, Los Angeles">
       Encino, California
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
       <a href="#cite_note-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      where Michael evolved from child performer into a teen idol.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Y25_38-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Y25-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As Jackson began to emerge as a solo performer in the early 1970s, he continued to maintain ties to the Jackson 5 and Motown. Between 1972, when his solo career began, and 1975, Michael released four solo studio albums with Motown:
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Got_to_Be_There" title="Got to Be There">
        Got to Be There
       </a>
      </i>
      (1972),
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Ben_(album)" title="Ben (album)">
        Ben
       </a>
      </i>
      (1972),
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Music_%26_Me" title="Music &amp; Me">
        Music &amp; Me
       </a>
      </i>
      (1973), and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Forever,_Michael" title="Forever, Michael">
        Forever, Michael
       </a>
      </i>
      (1975).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        39
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "
      <a href="/wiki/Got_to_Be_There_(song)" title="Got to Be There (song)">
       Got to Be There
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Ben_(song)" title="Ben (song)">
       Ben
      </a>
      ", the title tracks from his first two solo albums, both became successful singles, as did a remake of
      <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Day" title="Bobby Day">
       Bobby Day
      </a>
      's "
      <a href="/wiki/Rockin%27_Robin_(song)" title="Rockin' Robin (song)">
       Rockin' Robin
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        40
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Jackson 5 were later described as "a cutting-edge example of black crossover artists."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although the group's sales began declining in 1973, and the band members chafed under Motown's refusal to allow them creative control or input, they continued to score several top 40 hits, including the top five single, "
      <a href="/wiki/Dancing_Machine" title="Dancing Machine">
       Dancing Machine
      </a>
      " (1974), before the group left Motown in 1975.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G22_42-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G22-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1975.E2.80.9381:_Move_to_Epic_and_Off_the_Wall">
       197581: Move to Epic and
       <i>
        Off the Wall
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In June 1975, the Jackson 5 signed with
      <a href="/wiki/Epic_Records" title="Epic Records">
       Epic Records
      </a>
      , a subsidiary of
      <a href="/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment" title="Sony Music Entertainment">
       CBS Records
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G22_42-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G22-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and renamed themselves the Jacksons. Younger brother Randy formally joined the band around this time, while Jermaine chose to stay with Motown and pursue a solo career.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Jacksons continued to tour internationally, and released six more albums between 1976 and 1984. Michael, the group's lead songwriter during this time, wrote hits such as "
      <a href="/wiki/Shake_Your_Body_(Down_to_the_Ground)" title="Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)">
       Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)
      </a>
      " (1979), "
      <a href="/wiki/This_Place_Hotel" title="This Place Hotel">
       This Place Hotel
      </a>
      " (1980), and "
      <a href="/wiki/Can_You_Feel_It_(The_Jacksons_song)" title="Can You Feel It (The Jacksons song)">
       Can You Feel It
      </a>
      " (1980).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RRHF_30-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RRHF-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's work in film began in 1978, when he starred as the
      <a href="/wiki/Scarecrow_(Oz)" title="Scarecrow (Oz)">
       Scarecrow
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Wiz_(film)" title="The Wiz (film)">
        The Wiz
       </a>
      </i>
      , a musical directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Sidney_Lumet" title="Sidney Lumet">
       Sidney Lumet
      </a>
      that also starred
      <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">
       Diana Ross
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Nipsey_Russell" title="Nipsey Russell">
       Nipsey Russell
      </a>
      , and Ted Ross.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The film was a box-office disaster.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      While working on the film Jackson met
      <a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">
       Quincy Jones
      </a>
      , who was arranging the film's musical score, and Jones agreed to produce Jackson's next solo album,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall_(album)" title="Off the Wall (album)">
        Off the Wall
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G23_46-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G23-46">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        46
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1979, Jackson broke his nose during a complex dance routine. His subsequent
      <a href="/wiki/Rhinoplasty" title="Rhinoplasty">
       rhinoplasty
      </a>
      was not a complete success; he complained of breathing difficulties that would affect his career. He was referred to Dr.
      <a href="/wiki/Steven_Hoefflin" title="Steven Hoefflin">
       Steven Hoefflin
      </a>
      , who performed Jackson's second rhinoplasty and subsequent operations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T20510_47-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T20510-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <i>
       Off the Wall
      </i>
      (1979), which Jones and Jackson co-produced, established Jackson as a solo performer. The album helped Jackson transition from the "bubblegum pop" of his youth to the more complex sounds he would create as an adult.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Y25_38-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Y25-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Songwriters for the album included Jackson,
      <a href="/wiki/Rod_Temperton" title="Rod Temperton">
       Rod Temperton
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Stevie_Wonder" title="Stevie Wonder">
       Stevie Wonder
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">
       Paul McCartney
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       Off the Wall
      </i>
      was the first solo album to generate four top 10 hits in the United States: "Off the Wall", "Shes Out of My Life", and the chart-topping singles "
      <a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Stop_%27Til_You_Get_Enough" title="Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough">
       Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Rock_with_You_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Rock with You (Michael Jackson song)">
       Rock with You
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
       <a href="#cite_note-48">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        48
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        49
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The album reached number three on the
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">
       <i>
        Billboard
       </i>
       200
      </a>
      and eventually sold over 20 million copies worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        50
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1980, Jackson won three awards at the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Award" title="American Music Award">
       American Music Awards
      </a>
      for his solo efforts: Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Album, Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Male Artist, and Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Single for "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        51
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        52
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He also won
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Year-End" title="Billboard Year-End">
       Billboard Year-End
      </a>
      awards for Top Black Artist and Top Black Album, and a Grammy Award for Best Male R&amp;B Vocal Performance for 1979 with "Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
       <a href="#cite_note-53">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        53
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1981 Jackson was the American Music Awards winner for Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Album and Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Male Artist.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        54
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite its commercial success, Jackson felt
      <i>
       Off the Wall
      </i>
      should have made a much bigger impact, and was determined to exceed expectations with his next release.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1980, he secured the highest
      <a href="/wiki/Royalties" title="Royalties">
       royalty
      </a>
      rate in the music industry: 37 percent of wholesale album profit.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        56
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1982.E2.80.9383:_Thriller_and_Motown_25:_Yesterday.2C_Today.2C_Forever">
       198283:
       <i>
        Thriller
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In 1982, Jackson combined his interests in songwriting and film when he contributed the song "Someone in the Dark" to the
      <a href="/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial_(album)" title="E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (album)">
       storybook
      </a>
      for the film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial" title="E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial">
        E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial
       </a>
      </i>
      . The song, with Quincy Jones as its producer, won a Grammy for Best Recording for Children for 1983.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grammy_57-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grammy-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even more success came after the release of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Thriller (Michael Jackson album)">
        Thriller
       </a>
      </i>
      in late 1982. The album earned Jackson seven more Grammys
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grammy_57-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grammy-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and eight American Music Awards, including the Award of Merit, the youngest artist to win it.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Awards_1984_58-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Awards_1984-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      "Thriller" was the best-selling album worldwide in 1983.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        59
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        60
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It became the best-selling album of all time in the United States,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_albums" title="List of best-selling albums">
       best-selling album of all time worldwide
      </a>
      , selling an estimated
      <span class="nowrap">
       65 million
      </span>
      copies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The album topped the
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">
       <i>
        Billboard
       </i>
       200
      </a>
      chart for 37 weeks and was in the top 10 of the 200 for 80 consecutive weeks. It was the first album to have seven
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Hot 100 top 10 singles, including "
      <a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean" title="Billie Jean">
       Billie Jean
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Beat_It" title="Beat It">
       Beat It
      </a>
      ", and "
      <a href="/wiki/Wanna_Be_Startin%27_Somethin%27" title="Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'">
       Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        63
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In March 2009
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      was certified for 29 million shipments by the
      <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">
       RIAA
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        64
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      giving it
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_music_recording_certifications" title="List of music recording certifications">
       Double Diamond
      </a>
      status in the United States.
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      won Jackson and Quincy Jones the Grammy award for Producer of the Year (Non-Classical) for 1983. It also won Album of the Year, with Jackson as the album's artist and Jones as its co-producer, and a Best Pop Vocal Performance, Male, award for Jackson. "Beat It" won Record of the Year, with Jackson as artist and Jones as co-producer, and a Best Rock Vocal Performance, Male, award for Jackson. "Billie Jean" won Jackson two Grammy awards, Best R&amp;B Song, with Jackson as its songwriter, and Best R&amp;B Vocal Performance, Male, as its artist.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grammy_57-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grammy-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      also won another Grammy for Best Engineered Recording  Non Classical in 1984, awarding
      <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Swedien" title="Bruce Swedien">
       Bruce Swedien
      </a>
      for his work on the album.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce_65-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bruce-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The AMA Awards for 1984 provided Jackson with an Award of Merit and AMAs for Favorite Male Artist, Soul/R&amp;B, and Favorite Male Artist, Pop/Rock. "Beat It" won Jackson AMAs for Favorite Video, Soul/R&amp;B, Favorite Video, Pop/Rock, and Favorite Single, Pop/Rock.
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      won him AMAs for Favorite Album, Soul/R&amp;B, and Favorite Album, Pop/Rock.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Awards_1984_58-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Awards_1984-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In addition to the award-winning album, Jackson released "
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Thriller_(music_video)" title="Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)">
       Thriller
      </a>
      ", a fourteen-minute music video short directed by
      <a href="/wiki/John_Landis" title="John Landis">
       John Landis
      </a>
      , in 1983.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Registry_67-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Registry-67">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        67
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It "defined music videos and broke racial barriers" on the Music Television Channel (
      <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">
       MTV
      </a>
      ), a fledgling entertainment television channel at the time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Y25_38-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Y25-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In December 2009, the
      <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">
       Library of Congress
      </a>
      selected the music video for "Thriller" for inclusion in the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Film_Registry" title="National Film Registry">
       National Film Registry
      </a>
      . It was one of twenty-five films named that year as "works of enduring importance to American culture" that would be "preserved for all time."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The zombie-themed "Thriller" is the first and, as of 2009, the only music video to be inducted into the registry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Registry_67-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Registry-67">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        67
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_69-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
       <a href="#cite_note-70">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        70
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson's attorney
      <a href="/wiki/John_Branca" title="John Branca">
       John Branca
      </a>
      noted that Jackson had the highest royalty rate in the music industry at that point: approximately $2 for every album sold. He was also making record-breaking profits from sales of his recordings. The videocassette of the documentary
      <i>
       The Making of Michael Jackson's Thriller
      </i>
      sold over 350,000 copies in a few months. The era saw the arrival of novelties like dolls modeled after Michael Jackson, which appeared in stores in May 1984 at a price of $12.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TIME_71-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TIME-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Biographer
      <a href="/wiki/J._Randy_Taraborrelli" title="J. Randy Taraborrelli">
       J. Randy Taraborrelli
      </a>
      writes that, "
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      stopped selling like a leisure itemlike a magazine, a toy, tickets to a hit movieand started selling like a household staple."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        72
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1985,
      <i>
       The Making of Michael Jackson's Thriller
      </i>
      won a Grammy for Best Music Video, Longform.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grammy_57-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grammy-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Time
      </i>
      described Jackson's influence at that point as "Star of records, radio, rock video. A one-man rescue team for the music business. A songwriter who sets the beat for a decade. A dancer with the fanciest feet on the street. A singer who cuts across all boundaries of taste and style and color too".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TIME_71-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TIME-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       The New York Times
      </i>
      wrote that, "in the world of pop music, there is Michael Jackson and there is everybody else".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A defining point in Jackson's career took place on March 25, 1983, when he reunited with his brothers for a legendary live performance, which was taped at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium, for
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Motown_25:_Yesterday,_Today,_Forever" title="Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever">
        Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever
       </a>
      </i>
      , an NBC television special. The show aired on May 16, 1983, to an estimated audience of
      <span class="nowrap">
       47 million
      </span>
      viewers, and featured the Jacksons and other Motown stars.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        74
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The show is best remembered for Jackson's solo performance of "Billie Jean", which earned Jackson his first Emmy nomination.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emmys.tv_75-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-emmys.tv-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Wearing a distinctive black-
      <a href="/wiki/Sequin" title="Sequin">
       sequined
      </a>
      jacket and a golf glove decorated with rhinestones, he debuted his signature dance move, the
      <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(dance)" title="Moonwalk (dance)">
       moonwalk
      </a>
      , which former
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Soul_Train" title="Soul Train">
        Soul Train
       </a>
      </i>
      dancer and
      <a href="/wiki/Shalamar" title="Shalamar">
       Shalamar
      </a>
      member
      <a href="/wiki/Jeffrey_Daniel" title="Jeffrey Daniel">
       Jeffrey Daniel
      </a>
      had taught him three years earlier.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        76
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson originally turned down the invitation to perform at the show, believing he had been doing too much television at the time. However at the request of
      <a href="/wiki/Berry_Gordy" title="Berry Gordy">
       Berry Gordy
      </a>
      , Jackson relented and agreed to perform at the show in exchange for time to do a solo performance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to
      <i>
       Rolling Stone
      </i>
      reporter Mikal Gilmore, "There are times when you know you are hearing or seeing something extraordinary...that came that night."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Y25_38-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Y25-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's performance drew comparisons to
      <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">
       Elvis Presley
      </a>
      's and
      <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">
       the Beatles
      </a>
      ' appearances on
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Ed_Sullivan_Show" title="The Ed Sullivan Show">
        The Ed Sullivan Show
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        78
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Anna Kisselgoff of
      <i>
       The New York Times
      </i>
      later wrote, "The moonwalk that he made famous is an apt metaphor for his dance style. How does he do it? As a technician, he is a great illusionist, a genuine mime. His ability to keep one leg straight as he glides while the other bends and seems to walk requires perfect timing."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        79
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Berry Gordy said of the performance, "from the first beat of Billie Jean, I was mesmerized, and when he did his iconic moonwalk, I was shocked, it was magic, Michael Jackson went into orbit, and never came down."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        80
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1984.E2.80.9385:_Pepsi.2C_.22We_Are_the_World.22.2C_and_business_career">
       198485: Pepsi, "We Are the World", and business career
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      By the mid-1980s, Jackson's award-winning musical career contributed to his commercial appeal, which proved to be substantial. In November 1983 he, along with his brothers, partnered with
      <a href="/wiki/PepsiCo" title="PepsiCo">
       PepsiCo
      </a>
      in a $5 million promotional deal that broke advertising industry records for a celebrity endorsement. The first
      <a href="/wiki/Pepsi" title="Pepsi">
       Pepsi
      </a>
      campaign, which ran in the United States from 1983 to 1984 and launched its "New Generation" theme, included advertising, tour sponsorship, public relations events, and in-store displays. Jackson, who was actively involved in creating the iconic
      <a href="/wiki/Pepsi" title="Pepsi">
       Pepsi
      </a>
      advertisement, suggested using his song, "Billie Jean", as its musical jingle with a revised chorus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_81-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According a
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      report in 2009, Brian J. Murphy, executive VP of branded management at TBA Global, commented, "You couldn't separate the tour from the endorsement from the licensing of the music, and then the integration of the music into the Pepsi fabric."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_81-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On January 27, 1984, Michael and other members of the Jacksons filmed a Pepsi Cola commercial that was overseen by executive
      <a href="/wiki/Phil_Dusenberry" title="Phil Dusenberry">
       Phil Dusenberry
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        82
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      a
      <a href="/wiki/BBDO" title="BBDO">
       BBDO
      </a>
      ad agency executive, and
      <a href="/wiki/Alan_Pottasch" title="Alan Pottasch">
       Alan Pottasch
      </a>
      , Pepsi's Worldwide Creative Director, at the
      <a href="/wiki/Shrine_Auditorium" title="Shrine Auditorium">
       Shrine Auditorium
      </a>
      in Los Angeles. In front of a full house of fans during a simulated concert, pyrotechnics accidentally set Jackson's hair on fire, causing second-degree burns to his scalp. Jackson underwent treatment to hide the scars on his scalp, and had his third
      <a href="/wiki/Rhinoplasty" title="Rhinoplasty">
       rhinoplasty
      </a>
      shortly thereafter.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T20510_47-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T20510-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Pepsi settled out of court, and Jackson donated his $1.5 million settlement to the Brotman Medical Center in
      <a href="/wiki/Culver_City,_California" title="Culver City, California">
       Culver City
      </a>
      , California. Its Michael Jackson Burn Center is named in his honor.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Dusenberry later recounted the episode in his memoir,
      <i>
       Then We Set His Hair on Fire: Insights and Accidents from a Hall of Fame Career in Advertising
      </i>
      . Jackson signed a second agreement with Pepsi in the late 1980s for a reported $10 million. The second campaign had a global reach to more than twenty countries and provided financial support for Jackson's
      <i>
       Bad
      </i>
      album and his world tour in 198788.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_81-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although Jackson had endorsements and advertising deals with other companies, such as
      <a href="/wiki/LA_Gear" title="LA Gear">
       LA Gear
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Suzuki" title="Suzuki">
       Suzuki
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">
       Sony
      </a>
      , none were as significant as his deals with Pepsi, which later signed other music stars such as
      <a href="/wiki/Britney_Spears" title="Britney Spears">
       Britney Spears
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyonc">
       Beyonc
      </a>
      to promote its products.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_81-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrera2_81-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Herrera2-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        84
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg">
        <img alt="President Reagan wearing a suit and tie stands at a podium and turns to smile at Mrs Reagan, who is wearing a white outfit, and Jackson, who is wearing a white shirt with a blue jacket and a yellow strap across his chest." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="372" data-file-width="575" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg/220px-Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg/330px-Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg/440px-Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Reagans_with_Michael_Jackson.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson at the White House being presented with an award by President
        <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">
         Ronald Reagan
        </a>
        and first lady
        <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Reagan" title="Nancy Reagan">
         Nancy Reagan
        </a>
        , 1984.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Jackson's humanitarian work was recognized on May 14, 1984, when he was invited to the White House to receive an award from President
      <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">
       Ronald Reagan
      </a>
      for his support of charities that helped people overcome alcohol and drug abuse,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        85
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and in recognition of his support for the
      <a href="/wiki/Ad_Council" title="Ad Council">
       Ad Council
      </a>
      's and the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_Traffic_Safety_Administration" title="National Highway Traffic Safety Administration">
       National Highway Traffic Safety Administration
      </a>
      's Drunk Driving Prevention campaign. Jackson donated the use of "Beat It" for the campaign's public service announcements.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        86
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Unlike later albums,
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      did not have an official tour to promote it, but the
      <a href="/wiki/Victory_Tour_(The_Jacksons_tour)" title="Victory Tour (The Jacksons tour)">
       Victory Tour
      </a>
      of 1984 headlined the Jacksons and showcased much of Jackson's new solo material to more than two million Americans. It was the last tour he would do with his brothers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        87
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following a controversy over the concert's ticket sales, Jackson held a press conference and announced that he would donate his share of the proceeds from the Victory Tour, an estimated
      <span class="nowrap">
       $3 to 5 million
      </span>
      , to charity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        88
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        89
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's charitable work and humanitarian awards continued with the release of "
      <a href="/wiki/We_Are_the_World" title="We Are the World">
       We Are the World
      </a>
      " (1985), which he co-wrote with
      <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Richie" title="Lionel Richie">
       Lionel Richie
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WATW_90-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-WATW-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The song was recorded on January 28, 1985
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMAs_1986_91-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMAs_1986-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and was released worldwide in March 1985 to aid the poor in the United States and Africa.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The song earned $63 million for famine relief,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and became one of the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_singles" title="List of best-selling singles">
       best-selling singles of all time
      </a>
      , with 20 million copies sold.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        93
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "We Are the World" won four Grammys for 1985, including Song of the Year going to Jackson and Richie as its co-songwriters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WATW_90-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-WATW-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although the American Music Award directors removed the charity song from the competition because they felt it would be inappropriate, the AMA show in 1986 concluded with a tribute to the song in honor of its first anniversary. The project's creators received two special AMA honors: one for the creation of the song and another for the
      <a href="/wiki/USA_for_Africa" title="USA for Africa">
       USA for Africa
      </a>
      idea. Jackson, Quincy Jones, and entertainment promoter Ken Kragan received special awards for their roles in creation of the song.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WATW_90-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-WATW-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMAs_1986_91-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMAs_1986-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        94
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        95
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson's financial interests in the music publishing business expanded after collaborating with Paul McCartney in the early 1980s. He subsequently learned that McCartney made approximately $40 million a year from other people's songs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      By 1983, Jackson had begun investing in publishing rights to songs that others had written, but he was careful with his acquisitions, only bidding on a few of the dozens that were offered to him. Jackson's early acquisitions of
      <a href="/wiki/Music_catalog" title="Music catalog">
       music catalogs
      </a>
      and song copyrights such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Sly_Stone" title="Sly Stone">
       Sly Stone
      </a>
      collection included "Everyday People" (1968),
      <a href="/wiki/Len_Barry" title="Len Barry">
       Len Barry
      </a>
      's "
      <a href="/wiki/1-2-3_(Len_Barry_song)" title="1-2-3 (Len Barry song)">
       1-2-3
      </a>
      " (1965), and
      <a href="/wiki/Dion_DiMucci" title="Dion DiMucci">
       Dion DiMucci
      </a>
      's "
      <a href="/wiki/The_Wanderer_(Dion_song)" title="The Wanderer (Dion song)">
       The Wanderer
      </a>
      " (1961) and "
      <a href="/wiki/Runaround_Sue" title="Runaround Sue">
       Runaround Sue
      </a>
      " (1961); however, Jackson's most significant purchase came in 1985, when he acquired the publishing rights to
      <a href="/wiki/Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing#Acquisition" title="Sony/ATV Music Publishing">
       ATV Music Publishing
      </a>
      after months of negotiation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      ATV had acquired the publishing rights to nearly 4000 songs, including the
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Songs" title="Northern Songs">
       Northern Songs
      </a>
      catalog that contained the majority of the
      <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="LennonMcCartney">
       LennonMcCartney
      </a>
      compositions recorded by
      <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">
       the Beatles
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1984
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Holmes_%C3%A0_Court" title="Robert Holmes  Court">
       Robert Holmes  Court
      </a>
      , the wealthy Australian investor who owned ATV Music Publishing, announced he was putting the ATV catalog up for sale.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1981, McCartney was offered the ATV music catalog for 20 million ($40 million).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T3338_97-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T3338-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcca_atv_98-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mcca_atv-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to McCartney, he contacted
      <a href="/wiki/Yoko_Ono" title="Yoko Ono">
       Yoko Ono
      </a>
      about making a joint purchase by splitting the cost at 10 million each, but Ono thought they could buy it for 5 million each.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcca_atv_98-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-mcca_atv-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      When they were unable to make a joint purchase, McCartney, who did not want to be the sole owner of the Beatles' songs, did not pursue an offer on his own.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T3338_97-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T3338-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcca_atv_98-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-mcca_atv-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to a negotiator for Holmes  Court in the 1984 sale, "We had given Paul McCartney first right of refusal but Paul didn't want it at that time."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ch7news_99-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ch7news-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson was first informed about the sale by his attorney, John Branca, in September 1984.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      An attorney for McCartney also assured Branca that McCartney was not interested in bidding. McCartney reportedly said "It's too pricey",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jdoyle_92-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-jdoyle-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T3338_97-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-T3338-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      but several other companies and investors were interested in bidding. Jackson submitted a bid of $46 million on November 20, 1984.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His agents thought they had a deal several times, but encountered new bidders or new areas of debate. In May 1985, Jackson's team walked away from talks after having spent more than $1 million and four months of
      <a href="/wiki/Due_diligence" title="Due diligence">
       due diligence
      </a>
      work on the negotiations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In June 1985, Jackson and Branca learned that
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Koppelman" title="Charles Koppelman">
       Charles Koppelman
      </a>
      's and
      <a href="/wiki/Martin_Bandier" title="Martin Bandier">
       Marty Bandier
      </a>
      's The Entertainment Company had made a tentative agreement with Holmes  Court to buy ATV Music for $50 million; however, in early August, Holmes  Court's team contacted Jackson and talks resumed. Jackson raised his bid to $47.5 million, which was accepted because he could close the deal more quickly, having already completed due diligence of ATV Music.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson also agreed to visit Holmes  Court in Australia, where he would appear on the
      <a href="/wiki/Channel_Seven_Perth_Telethon" title="Channel Seven Perth Telethon">
       Channel Seven Perth Telethon
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ch7news_99-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ch7news-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's
      <a href="/wiki/Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing#Acquisition" title="Sony/ATV Music Publishing">
       purchase of ATV Music
      </a>
      was finalized on August 10, 1985.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hilburn_96-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-hilburn-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1986.E2.80.9390:_Appearance.2C_tabloids.2C_Bad.2C_films.2C_autobiography.2C_and_Neverland">
       198690: Appearance, tabloids,
       <i>
        Bad
       </i>
       , films, autobiography, and Neverland
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_health_and_appearance" title="Michael Jackson's health and appearance">
       Michael Jackson's health and appearance
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Jackson's skin had been a medium-brown color for the entire duration of his youth, but starting in the mid-1980s, it gradually grew paler. The change gained widespread media coverage, including rumors that he might be bleaching his skin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-C146_100-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-C146-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to
      <a href="/wiki/J._Randy_Taraborrelli" title="J. Randy Taraborrelli">
       J. Randy Taraborrelli
      </a>
      's biography, in 1986, Jackson was diagnosed with
      <a href="/wiki/Vitiligo" title="Vitiligo">
       vitiligo
      </a>
      which Taraborrelli noted, may be a consequence of skin bleaching. He claimed Jackson was diagnosed with
      <a href="/wiki/Systemic_lupus_erythematosus" title="Systemic lupus erythematosus">
       lupus
      </a>
      ; the vitiligo partially lightened his skin, and the lupus was in
