      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Remission_(medicine)" title="Remission (medicine)">
       remission
      </a>
      ; both illnesses made him sensitive to sunlight. The treatments he used for his condition further lightened his skin tone and, with the application of pancake makeup to even out blotches, he could appear very pale.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
       <a href="#cite_note-101">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        101
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson was also diagnosed with vitiligo in his autopsy though not with lupus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
       <a href="#cite_note-102">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        102
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson claimed that he had only two rhinoplasties and no other surgery on his face, although at one point he mentioned having a dimple created in his chin. Jackson lost weight in the early 1980s because of a change in diet and a desire for "a dancer's body".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J22930_103-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-J22930-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Witnesses reported that he was often dizzy and speculated that he was suffering from
      <a href="/wiki/Anorexia_nervosa" title="Anorexia nervosa">
       anorexia nervosa
      </a>
      ; periods of weight loss would become a recurring problem later in life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        104
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During the course of his treatment, Jackson made two close friends: his dermatologist, Dr.
      <a href="/wiki/Arnold_Klein" title="Arnold Klein">
       Arnold Klein
      </a>
      , and Klein's nurse
      <a href="/wiki/Debbie_Rowe" title="Debbie Rowe">
       Debbie Rowe
      </a>
      . Rowe eventually became Jackson's second wife and the mother of his two eldest children. He also relied heavily on Klein for medical and business advice.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
       <a href="#cite_note-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson became the subject of increasingly sensational reports. In 1986, the tabloids ran a story claiming that Jackson slept in a
      <a href="/wiki/Hyperbaric_medicine" title="Hyperbaric medicine">
       hyperbaric oxygen chamber
      </a>
      to slow the aging process; he was pictured lying down in a glass box. Although the claim was untrue, according to tabloid reports that are widely cited, Jackson had disseminated the fabricated story himself.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Image_106-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Image-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      When Jackson bought a chimpanzee called
      <a href="/wiki/Bubbles_(chimpanzee)" title="Bubbles (chimpanzee)">
       Bubbles
      </a>
      from a laboratory, he was reported to be increasingly detached from reality.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        107
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was reported that Jackson had offered to buy the bones of
      <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Merrick" title="Joseph Merrick">
       Joseph Merrick
      </a>
      (the "Elephant Man") and, although untrue, Jackson did not deny the story.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T35561_108-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T35561-108">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        108
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although he initially saw these stories as opportunities for publicity, he stopped leaking untruths to the press as they became more sensational. Consequently, the media began making up their own stories.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Image_106-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Image-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T3703_109-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T3703-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        110
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      These reports became embedded in the public consciousness, inspiring the nickname "Wacko Jacko", which Jackson came to despise.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        111
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Responding to the gossip, Jackson remarked to Taraborrelli:
     </p>
     <blockquote>
      <p>
       Why not just tell people I'm an alien from Mars? Tell them I eat live chickens and do a voodoo dance at midnight. They'll believe anything
       <i>
        you
       </i>
       say, because
       <i>
        you're a reporter
       </i>
       . But if I, Michael Jackson, were to say, "I'm an alien from Mars and I eat live chickens and do a voodoo dance at midnight," people would say, "Oh, man, that Michael Jackson is
       <i>
        nuts
       </i>
       . He's cracked up. You can't believe a single word that comes out of his mouth."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         112
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg">
        <img alt="A black jacket with five round golden medals on its left and right shoulders, a gold band on its left arm sleeve, and two belt straps on the right bottom sleeve. Underneath the jacket is a golden belt, with a round ornament in its center." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2318" data-file-width="2047" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson%27s_%22Bad%22_Jacket_and_Belt.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson wore a gold-plated military style jacket with belt during the
        <i>
         Bad
        </i>
        era.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Jackson collaborated with
      <a href="/wiki/George_Lucas" title="George Lucas">
       George Lucas
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola" title="Francis Ford Coppola">
       Francis Ford Coppola
      </a>
      on the 17-minute
      <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">
       3D film
      </a>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Captain_EO" title="Captain EO">
        Captain EO
       </a>
      </i>
      , which debuted in September 1986 at both the original
      <a href="/wiki/Disneyland" title="Disneyland">
       Disneyland
      </a>
      and at
      <a href="/wiki/Epcot" title="Epcot">
       Epcot
      </a>
      in Florida, and in March 1987 at
      <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Disneyland" title="Tokyo Disneyland">
       Tokyo Disneyland
      </a>
      . The $30 million movie was a popular attraction at all three parks. A Captain EO attraction was later featured at
      <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Park_(Paris)" title="Disneyland Park (Paris)">
       Euro Disneyland
      </a>
      after that park opened in 1992. All four parks' Captain EO installations stayed open well into the 1990s: the Paris installation was the last one to close, in 1998.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        113
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The attraction would later return to Disneyland in 2010 after Jackson's death.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        114
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1987, Jackson disassociated himself from the
      <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">
       Jehovah's Witnesses
      </a>
      , in response to their disapproval of the
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      video.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        115
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        116
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the industry expecting another major hit, Jackson's first album in five years,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Bad_(album)" title="Bad (album)">
        Bad
       </a>
      </i>
      (1987), was highly anticipated.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TIME2_117-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TIME2-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson-3.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1181" data-file-width="594" height="338" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Michael_Jackson-3.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson-3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Michael_Jackson-3.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson-3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Michael_Jackson-3.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson-3.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson-3.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson performing in 1988.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The album spawned seven hit singles in the U.S., five of which ("
      <a href="/wiki/I_Just_Can%27t_Stop_Loving_You" title="I Just Can't Stop Loving You">
       I Just Can't Stop Loving You
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Bad_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Bad (Michael Jackson song)">
       Bad
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/The_Way_You_Make_Me_Feel" title="The Way You Make Me Feel">
       The Way You Make Me Feel
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Man_in_the_Mirror" title="Man in the Mirror">
       Man in the Mirror
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Dirty_Diana" title="Dirty Diana">
       Dirty Diana
      </a>
      ") reached number one on the
      <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">
       <i>
        Billboard
       </i>
       Hot 100
      </a>
      . This was a record for most number one Hot 100 singles from any one album, including
      <i>
       Thriller.
      </i>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        118
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2012, the album sold between 30 to 45 million copies worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        119
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        120
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
       <a href="#cite_note-121">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        121
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        122
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Thanks to the
      <i>
       Bad
      </i>
      album, Bruce Swedien and
      <a href="/wiki/Humberto_Gatica" title="Humberto Gatica">
       Humberto Gatica
      </a>
      won one Grammy in 1988 for Best Engineered Recording  Non Classical and Michael Jackson won one Grammy for Best Music Video, Short Form for "
      <a href="/wiki/Leave_Me_Alone" title="Leave Me Alone">
       Leave Me Alone
      </a>
      " in 1989.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grammy_57-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grammy-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce_65-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bruce-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the same year, Jackson won an Award of Achievement at the American Music Awards because
      <i>
       Bad
      </i>
      is the first album ever to generate five number one singles in the U.S., the first album to top in 25 countries, and the best-selling album worldwide in 1987 and 1988.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
       <a href="#cite_note-123">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        123
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        124
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        125
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
       <a href="#cite_note-126">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        126
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1988, "Bad" won an American Music Award for Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Single.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
       <a href="#cite_note-127">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        127
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Bad_(tour)" title="Bad (tour)">
       Bad World Tour
      </a>
      began on September 12 that year, finishing on January 14, 1989.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LJ956_128-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-LJ956-128">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        128
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In Japan alone, the tour had 14 sellouts and drew 570,000 people, nearly tripling the previous record of 200,000 in a single tour.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
       <a href="#cite_note-129">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        129
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson broke a
      <i>
       Guinness World Record
      </i>
      when 504,000 people attended seven sold-out shows at
      <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_(1923)" title="Wembley Stadium (1923)">
       Wembley Stadium
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
       <a href="#cite_note-130">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        130
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He performed a total of 123 concerts to an audience of 4.4 million people.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        131
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1988, Jackson released his only autobiography,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Moonwalk_(book)" title="Moonwalk (book)">
        Moonwalk
       </a>
      </i>
      , which took four years to complete and sold 200,000 copies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
       <a href="#cite_note-132">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        132
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson wrote about his childhood,
      <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">
       the Jackson 5
      </a>
      , and the abuse he had suffered.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        133
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He also wrote about his facial appearance, saying he had had two rhinoplastic surgeries and a
      <a href="/wiki/Cleft_chin" title="Cleft chin">
       dimple
      </a>
      created in his chin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J22930_103-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-J22930-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He attributed much of the change in the structure of his face to
      <a href="/wiki/Puberty" title="Puberty">
       puberty
      </a>
      , weight loss, a strict vegetarian diet, a change in hair style, and stage lighting.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J22930_103-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-J22930-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Moonwalk
      </i>
      reached the top position on
      <i>
       The New York Times
      </i>
      best sellers' list.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        134
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The musician then released a film called
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Moonwalker" title="Moonwalker">
        Moonwalker
       </a>
      </i>
      , which featured live footage and short films that starred Jackson and
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Pesci" title="Joe Pesci">
       Joe Pesci
      </a>
      . The film was originally intended to be released to theaters, but due to financial issues, the film was released
      <a href="/wiki/Direct-to-video" title="Direct-to-video">
       direct-to-video
      </a>
      . It saw a theatrical release in Germany, though. It debuted atop the
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Top Music Video Cassette chart, staying there for 22 weeks. It was eventually knocked off the top spot by
      <i>
       Michael Jackson: The Legend Continues
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G434_135-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G434-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In March 1988, Jackson purchased land near
      <a href="/wiki/Santa_Ynez,_California" title="Santa Ynez, California">
       Santa Ynez
      </a>
      , California, to build
      <a href="/wiki/Neverland_Ranch" title="Neverland Ranch">
       Neverland Ranch
      </a>
      at a cost of $17 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malta_136-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Malta-136">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        136
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He installed several carnival rides on the 2,700-acre (11km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      ) property, including a
      <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">
       Ferris wheel
      </a>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Carousel" title="Carousel">
       carousel
      </a>
      , and a
      <a href="/wiki/Menagerie" title="Menagerie">
       menagerie
      </a>
      , as well as a movie theater and a zoo.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malta_136-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Malta-136">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        136
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio2_137-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bio2-137">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        137
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        138
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A security staff of 40 patrolled the grounds.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio2_137-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bio2-137">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        137
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2003, it was valued at approximately $100 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finances_139-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Finances-139">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        139
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1989, his annual earnings from album sales, endorsements, and concerts were estimated at $125 million for that year alone.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Records_140-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-World_Records-140">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        140
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Shortly afterwards, he became the first Westerner to appear in a television ad in the
      <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">
       Soviet Union
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G434_135-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G434-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      His success resulted in him being dubbed the "
      <a href="/wiki/Honorific_nicknames_in_popular_music" title="Honorific nicknames in popular music">
       King of Pop
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LJ3_4-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-LJ3-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arar_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Arar-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SBee_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SBee-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The nickname was popularized by
      <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_Taylor" title="Elizabeth Taylor">
       Elizabeth Taylor
      </a>
      when she presented him with the Soul Train Heritage Award in 1989, proclaiming him "the true king of pop, rock and soul."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        141
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      President
      <a href="/wiki/George_H._W._Bush" title="George H. W. Bush">
       George H. W. Bush
      </a>
      designated him the White House's "Artist of the Decade".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
       <a href="#cite_note-142">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        142
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      From 1985 to 1990, he donated $455,000 to the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Negro_College_Fund" title="United Negro College Fund">
       United Negro College Fund
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        143
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and all of the profits from his single "Man in the Mirror" went to charity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        144
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's live rendition of "You Were There" at
      <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis_Jr." title="Sammy Davis Jr.">
       Sammy Davis Jr.
      </a>
      's 60th birthday celebration allowed Jackson to receive his second Emmy nomination.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emmys.tv_75-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-emmys.tv-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G434_135-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G434-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1991.E2.80.9393:_Dangerous.2C_Heal_the_World_Foundation.2C_and_Super_Bowl_XXVII">
       199193:
       <i>
        Dangerous
       </i>
       , Heal the World Foundation, and Super Bowl XXVII
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In March 1991, Jackson renewed his contract with Sony for $65 million, a record-breaking deal at the time,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        145
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      displacing
      <a href="/wiki/Neil_Diamond" title="Neil Diamond">
       Neil Diamond
      </a>
      's renewal contract with
      <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">
       Columbia Records
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        146
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1991, he released his eighth album,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Dangerous_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Dangerous (Michael Jackson album)">
        Dangerous
       </a>
      </i>
      , co-produced with
      <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Riley" title="Teddy Riley">
       Teddy Riley
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
       <a href="#cite_note-147">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        147
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      was certified seven times platinum in the U.S., and, as of 2008, has approximately sold 30 million copies worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_148-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Certifications-148">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        148
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        149
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the United States, the album's first single "
      <a href="/wiki/Black_or_White" title="Black or White">
       Black or White
      </a>
      " was its biggest hit, reaching number one on the
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Hot 100 and remaining there for seven weeks, with similar chart performances worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_150-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Achievements-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The album's second single "
      <a href="/wiki/Remember_the_Time" title="Remember the Time">
       Remember the Time
      </a>
      " spent eight weeks in the top five in the United States, peaking at number three on the
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Hot 100 singles chart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the end of 1992,
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      was awarded the best-selling album of the year worldwide and "Black or White" was awarded best-selling single of the year worldwide at the Billboard Music Awards. Additionally, he won an award as best-selling artist of the 1980s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        152
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1993, Jackson performed the song at the
      <a href="/wiki/Soul_Train_Music_Awards" title="Soul Train Music Awards">
       Soul Train Music Awards
      </a>
      in a chair, saying he had suffered an injury in rehearsals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
       <a href="#cite_note-153">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        153
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the UK and other parts of Europe, "
      <a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World" title="Heal the World">
       Heal the World
      </a>
      " was the biggest hit from the album; it sold 450,000 copies in the UK and spent five weeks at number two in 1992.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson founded the
      <a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World_Foundation" title="Heal the World Foundation">
       Heal the World Foundation
      </a>
      in 1992. The charity organization brought underprivileged children to Jackson's ranch to enjoy theme park rides that Jackson had built on the property. The foundation also sent millions of dollars around the globe to help children threatened by war, poverty, and disease. In the same year Jackson published his second book, the bestselling collection of poetry,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Dancing_the_Dream" title="Dancing the Dream">
        Dancing the Dream
       </a>
      </i>
      . While it was a commercial success, and revealed a more intimate side to Jackson's nature, the collection was mostly critically unacclaimed at the time of its release. In 2009, the book was republished by
      <a href="/wiki/Doubleday_(publisher)" title="Doubleday (publisher)">
       Doubleday
      </a>
      and was more positively received by some critics in the wake of Jackson's untimely death. The
      <a href="/wiki/Dangerous_World_Tour" title="Dangerous World Tour">
       Dangerous World Tour
      </a>
      grossed
      <span class="nowrap">
       $100 million
      </span>
      . The tour began on June 27, 1992, and finished on November 11, 1993. Jackson performed to 3.5 million people in 70 concerts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
       <a href="#cite_note-154">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        154
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He sold the broadcast rights to his
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      world tour to
      <a href="/wiki/HBO" title="HBO">
       HBO
      </a>
      for $20 million, a record-breaking deal that still stands.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        155
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Following the illness and death of
      <a href="/wiki/Ryan_White" title="Ryan White">
       Ryan White
      </a>
      , Jackson helped draw public attention to HIV/AIDS, something that was still controversial at the time. He publicly pleaded with the
      <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Bill_Clinton" title="Presidency of Bill Clinton">
       Clinton Administration
      </a>
      at Bill Clinton's Inaugural Gala to give more money to HIV/AIDS charities and research.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        156
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        157
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In a high-profile visit to Africa, Jackson visited several countries, among them
      <a href="/wiki/Gabon" title="Gabon">
       Gabon
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">
       Egypt
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebony_158-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ebony-158">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        158
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His first stop to Gabon was greeted with a sizable and enthusiastic reception of more than 100,000 people, some of them carrying signs that read, "Welcome Home Michael."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebony_158-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ebony-158">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        158
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In his trip to
      <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast" title="Ivory Coast">
       Ivory Coast
      </a>
      , Jackson was crowned "King Sani" by a tribal chief.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebony_158-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ebony-158">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        158
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He then thanked the dignitaries in French and English, signed official documents formalizing his kingship, and sat on a golden throne while presiding over ceremonial dances.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ebony_158-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ebony-158">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        158
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In January 1993, Jackson made a memorable appearance at the halftime show at
      <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXVII" title="Super Bowl XXVII">
       Super Bowl XXVII
      </a>
      . Because of dwindling interest during halftime in the years before, the NFL decided to seek big-name talent that would keep viewers and ratings high, with Jackson being selected because of his popularity and universal appeal.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
       <a href="#cite_note-159">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        159
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was the first Super Bowl where the audience figures increased during the half-time show to more than the game itself. The performance began with Jackson catapulting onto the stage as fireworks went off behind him. As he landed on the canvas, he maintained a motionless "clenched fist, standing statue stance", dressed in a gold and black military outfit and sunglasses; he remained completely motionless for a minute and a half while the crowd cheered. He then slowly removed his sunglasses, threw them away and sang four songs: "
      <a href="/wiki/Jam_(song)" title="Jam (song)">
       Jam
      </a>
      ", "Billie Jean", "Black or White", and "Heal the World". Jackson's
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      album rose 90 places up the album chart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-C146_100-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-C146-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson gave a 90-minute interview to
      <a href="/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey" title="Oprah Winfrey">
       Oprah Winfrey
      </a>
      on February 10, 1993, his second television interview since 1979. He grimaced when speaking of his childhood abuse at the hands of his father; he believed he had missed out on much of his childhood years, admitting that he often cried from loneliness. He denied tabloid rumors that he had bought the bones of
      <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Merrick" title="Joseph Merrick">
       the Elephant Man
      </a>
      , slept in a hyperbaric oxygen chamber, or bleached his skin, stating for the first time that he had
      <a href="/wiki/Vitiligo" title="Vitiligo">
       vitiligo
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      re-entered the album chart in the top 10, more than a year after its original release.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LJ1658_25-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-LJ1658-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-C146_100-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-C146-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In February 1993, Jackson was given the "Living Legend Award" at the
      <a href="/wiki/35th_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="35th Annual Grammy Awards">
       35th Annual Grammy Awards
      </a>
      in Los Angeles. "Black or White" was Grammy-nominated for best vocal performance. "Jam" gained two nominations: Best R&amp;B Vocal Performance and Best R&amp;B Song.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      album won a Grammy for Best Engineered  Non Classical, awarding the work of Bruce Swedien and Teddy Riley.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bruce_65-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bruce-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the same year, Michael Jackson won three American Music Awards for Favorite Pop/Rock Album (
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      ), Favorite Soul/R&amp;B Single ("
      <a href="/wiki/Remember_the_Time" title="Remember the Time">
       Remember the Time
      </a>
      "), and was the first to win the International Artist Award, for his global performances and humanitarian concerns. This award will bear his name in the future.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
       <a href="#cite_note-160">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        160
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
       <a href="#cite_note-161">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        161
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1993.E2.80.9394:_First_child_sexual_abuse_allegations_and_first_marriage">
       199394: First child sexual abuse allegations and first marriage
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/1993_child_sexual_abuse_accusations_against_Michael_Jackson" title="1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson">
       1993 child sexual abuse accusations against Michael Jackson
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In the summer of 1993, Jackson was accused of
      <a href="/wiki/Child_sexual_abuse" title="Child sexual abuse">
       child sexual abuse
      </a>
      by a 13-year-old boy named Jordan Chandler and his father,
      <a href="/wiki/Evan_Chandler" title="Evan Chandler">
       Evan Chandler
      </a>
      , a dentist.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abuse_162-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Abuse-162">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        162
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        163
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T4778_164-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T4778-164">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        164
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Chandler family demanded payment from Jackson, and the singer initially refused. Jordan Chandler eventually told the police that Jackson had sexually abused him.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T35561_108-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T35561-108">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        108
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
       <a href="#cite_note-165">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        165
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Evan Chandler was tape-recorded discussing his intention to pursue charges, saying, "If I go through with this, I win big-time. There's no way I lose. I will get everything I want and they will be destroyed forever..... Michael's career will be over". Jordan's mother was, however, adamant at the time that there had been no wrongdoing on Jackson's part.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T4778_164-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T4778-164">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        164
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson later used the recording to argue that he was the victim of a jealous father whose only goal was to extort money from the singer.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T4778_164-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-T4778-164">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        164
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In January 1994, however, after investigation on allegations of extortion against the singer by Chandler, deputy Los Angeles County district attorney Michael J. Montagna stated that Chandler would not be charged due to lack of cooperation from Jackson's camp and its willingness to negotiate with Chandler for several weeks among other reasons.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        166
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In August 1993, Jackson's home was raided by the police who, according to court documents, found books and photographs in his bedroom featuring young boys with little or no clothing.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        167
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the books were legal to purchase and own, the jury decided to not indict Jackson.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
       <a href="#cite_note-168">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        168
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In December 1993, Jackson was
      <a href="/wiki/Strip_search" title="Strip search">
       strip searched
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T53440_169-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T53440-169">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        169
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jordan Chandler had reportedly given police a description of Jackson's
      <a href="/wiki/Intimate_part" title="Intimate part">
       intimate parts
      </a>
      , and the strip search revealed that Jordan had correctly claimed Jackson had patchy-colored buttocks, short
      <a href="/wiki/Pubic_hair" title="Pubic hair">
       pubic hair
      </a>
      , and pink and brown marked
      <a href="/wiki/Testicle" title="Testicle">
       testicles
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T53440_169-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T53440-169">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        169
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Reportedly, Jordan had also previously drawn accurate pictures of a dark spot on Jackson's penis only visible when his penis was lifted.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        170
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite differing initial internal reports from prosecutors and investigators
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        171
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and later, with reports of jurors feeling otherwise that the photos did not match the description,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accuser_172-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Accuser-172">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        172
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      the DA stated his belief in a sworn
      <a href="/wiki/Affidavit" title="Affidavit">
       affidavit
      </a>
      that the description was accurate,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
       <a href="#cite_note-173">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        173
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      along with the sheriff's photographer stating the description was accurate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        174
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A 2004 motion filed by Jackson's defense asserted that Jackson was never criminally indicted by any grand jury and that his settlement admitted no wrongdoing and contained no evidence of criminal misconduct.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Court_175-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Court-175">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        175
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The investigation was inconclusive and no charges were ever filed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accuser_172-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Accuser-172">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        172
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson described the search in an emotional public statement, and proclaimed his innocence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abuse_162-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Abuse-162">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        162
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T53440_169-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-T53440-169">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        169
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        176
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On January 1, 1994, Jackson settled with the Chandlers out of court for $22 million. A Santa Barbara County grand jury and a Los Angeles County grand jury disbanded on May 2, 1994, without indicting Jackson,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        177
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the Chandlers stopped co-operating with the criminal investigation around July 6, 1994.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Court_175-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Court-175">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        175
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        178
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        179
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The out-of-court settlement's documentation specifically stated Jackson admitted no wrongdoing and no liability; the Chandlers and their family lawyer Larry Feldman signed it without contest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
       <a href="#cite_note-180">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        180
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Feldman also explicitly stated "nobody bought anybody's silence".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
       <a href="#cite_note-181">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        181
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A decade after the fact, during the second round of child abuse allegations, Jackson's lawyers would file a memo stating that the 1994 settlement was done without his consent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Court_175-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Court-175">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        175
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A later disclosure by the
      <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">
       FBI
      </a>
      of investigation documents compiled over nearly 20 years led to Jackson's attorney to make the suggestion that there was no evidence of molestation or sexual impropriety from Jackson towards minors.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
       <a href="#cite_note-182">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        182
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to reports the
      <a href="/wiki/Child_Protective_Services" title="Child Protective Services">
       DCFS
      </a>
      had investigated Jackson beginning in 1993 with the Chandler allegation and again in 2003. Reports show the
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Police_Department" title="Los Angeles Police Department">
       LAPD
      </a>
      and DCFS did not find credible evidence of abuse or sexual misconduct.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
       <a href="#cite_note-183">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        183
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
       <a href="#cite_note-184">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        184
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SG2003_185-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SG2003-185">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        185
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In May 1994, Jackson married
      <a href="/wiki/Lisa_Marie_Presley" title="Lisa Marie Presley">
       Lisa Marie Presley
      </a>
      , the daughter of
      <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">
       Elvis
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Priscilla_Presley" title="Priscilla Presley">
       Priscilla Presley
      </a>
      . They had first met in 1975, when a seven-year-old Presley attended one of Jackson's family engagements at the
      <a href="/wiki/Bally%27s_Las_Vegas" title="Bally's Las Vegas">
       MGM Grand Hotel and Casino
      </a>
      , and were reconnected through a mutual friend.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
       <a href="#cite_note-186">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        186
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to a friend of Presley's, "their adult friendship began in November 1992 in L.A."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
       <a href="#cite_note-187">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        187
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      They stayed in contact every day over the telephone. As the child molestation accusations became public, Jackson became dependent on Presley for emotional support; she was concerned about his faltering health and addiction to drugs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T51820_188-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T51820-188">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        188
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Presley explained, "I believed he didn't do anything wrong and that he was wrongly accused and yes I started falling for him. I wanted to save him. I felt that I could do it."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
       <a href="#cite_note-189">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        189
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      She eventually persuaded him to settle the civil case out of court and go into rehabilitation to recover.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T51820_188-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T51820-188">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        188
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson proposed to Presley over the telephone towards the fall of 1993, saying, "If I asked you to marry me, would you do it?"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T51820_188-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-T51820-188">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        188
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      They married in the
      <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">
       Dominican Republic
      </a>
      in secrecy, denying it for nearly two months afterwards.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divorce_190-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Divorce-190">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        190
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The marriage was, in her words, "a married couple's life..... that was sexually active".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        191
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the time, the tabloid media speculated that the wedding was a ploy to prop up Jackson's public image.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divorce_190-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Divorce-190">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        190
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The marriage lasted less than two years and ended with an amicable divorce settlement.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T5801_192-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T5801-192">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        192
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In a 2010 interview with Oprah, Presley admitted that they spent four more years after the divorce "getting back together and breaking up", until she decided to stop.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
       <a href="#cite_note-193">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        193
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1995.E2.80.9399:_HIStory.2C_second_marriage.2C_and_fatherhood">
       199599:
       <i>
        HIStory
       </i>
       , second marriage, and fatherhood
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In 1995, Jackson merged his ATV Music catalog with Sony's music publishing division creating
      <a href="/wiki/Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing" title="Sony/ATV Music Publishing">
       Sony/ATV Music Publishing
      </a>
      . Jackson retained half-ownership of the company, earned $95 million upfront as well as
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing_artists" title="List of Sony/ATV Music Publishing artists">
       the rights to even more songs
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
       <a href="#cite_note-194">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        194
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sonydeal_195-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-sonydeal-195">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        195
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He then released the double album
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/HIStory:_Past,_Present_and_Future,_Book_I" title="HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I">
        HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I
       </a>
      </i>
      . The first disc,
      <i>
       HIStory Begins
      </i>
      , was a 15-track greatest hits album, and was later reissued as
      <i>
       Greatest Hits: HIStory, Volume I
      </i>
      in 2001, while the second disc,
      <i>
       HIStory Continues
      </i>
      , contained 13 new songs and 2 cover versions. The album debuted at number one on the charts and has been certified for seven million shipments in the US.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
       <a href="#cite_note-196">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        196
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is the best-selling multiple-disc album of all-time, with 20 million copies (40 million units) sold worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_150-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Achievements-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
       <a href="#cite_note-197">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        197
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       HIStory
      </i>
      received a Grammy nomination for
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Album of the Year">
       Album of the Year
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The first single released from the album was "
      <a href="/wiki/Scream/Childhood" title="Scream/Childhood">
       Scream/Childhood
      </a>
      ". "Scream" was a duet, performed with Jackson's youngest sister
      <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">
       Janet
      </a>
      . The song fights against the media, mainly for what the media made him out to be during his 1993 child abuse allegations. The single had the highest debut on the
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Hot 100 at number five, and received a Grammy nomination for "Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "
      <a href="/wiki/You_Are_Not_Alone" title="You Are Not Alone">
       You Are Not Alone
      </a>
      " was the second single released from
      <i>
       HIStory
      </i>
      ; it holds the
      <i>
       Guinness World Record
      </i>
      for the first song ever to debut at number one on the
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Hot 100 chart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Records_140-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-World_Records-140">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        140
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was seen as a major artistic and commercial success, receiving a Grammy nomination for "Best Pop Vocal Performance".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg">
        <img alt="Close-up of a pale skinned Jackson with black hair. He is wearing a black jacket with white designs on it." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="567" data-file-width="417" height="231" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Cannescropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Michael Jackson at the
        <a href="/wiki/1997_Cannes_Film_Festival" title="1997 Cannes Film Festival">
         1997 Cannes Film Festival
        </a>
        for the
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Ghosts" title="Michael Jackson's Ghosts">
          Ghosts
         </a>
        </i>
        music video premiere.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In late 1995, Jackson was rushed to a hospital after collapsing during rehearsals for a televised performance; the incident was caused by a stress-related
      <a href="/wiki/Panic_attack" title="Panic attack">
       panic attack
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
       <a href="#cite_note-199">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        199
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "
      <a href="/wiki/Earth_Song" title="Earth Song">
       Earth Song
      </a>
      " was the third single released from
      <i>
       HIStory
      </i>
      , and topped the
      <a href="/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart" title="UK Singles Chart">
       UK Singles Chart
      </a>
      for six weeks over Christmas 1995; it sold a million copies, making it Jackson's most successful single in the UK.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The track "
      <a href="/wiki/They_Don%27t_Care_About_Us" title="They Don't Care About Us">
       They Don't Care About Us
      </a>
      " became controversial when the
      <a href="/wiki/Anti-Defamation_League" title="Anti-Defamation League">
       Anti-Defamation League
      </a>
      and other groups criticized its allegedly
      <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism" title="Antisemitism">
       antisemitic
      </a>
      lyrics. Jackson quickly put out a revised version of the song without the offending lyrics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ADL_200-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ADL-200">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        200
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1996, Jackson won a Grammy for Best Music Video, Short Form for "Scream" and an American Music Award for Favorite Pop/Rock Male Artist.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grammy_57-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grammy-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
       <a href="#cite_note-201">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        201
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The album was promoted with the successful
      <a href="/wiki/HIStory_World_Tour" title="HIStory World Tour">
       HIStory World Tour
      </a>
      . The tour began on September 7, 1996, and finished on October 15, 1997. Jackson performed 82 concerts in 58 cities to over 4.5 million fans, and grossed a total of
      <span class="nowrap">
       $165 million
      </span>
      . The show, which visited five continents and 35 countries, became Jackson's most successful in terms of audience figures.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LJ956_128-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-LJ956-128">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        128
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      During the tour, Jackson married his
      <a href="/wiki/Personal_relationships_of_Michael_Jackson#Debbie_Rowe" title="Personal relationships of Michael Jackson">
       longtime friend
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Debbie_Rowe" title="Debbie Rowe">
       Deborah Jeanne Rowe
      </a>
      , a dermatology nurse, in an impromptu ceremony in Sydney, Australia. Rowe was approximately six months pregnant with the couple's first child at the time. Originally, Rowe and Jackson had no plans to marry, but Jackson's mother Katherine persuaded them to do so.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
       <a href="#cite_note-202">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        202
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Michael Joseph Jackson Jr (commonly known as Prince) was born on February 13, 1997; his sister Paris-Michael Katherine Jackson was born a year later on April 3, 1998.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T5801_192-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T5801-192">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        192
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        203
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The couple divorced in 1999, and Jackson got full custody of the children. The divorce was relatively amicable, but a subsequent custody suit was not settled until 2006.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T599600_204-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T599600-204">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        204
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ex_wife_205-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ex_wife-205">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        205
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1997, Jackson released
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Blood_on_the_Dance_Floor:_HIStory_in_the_Mix" title="Blood on the Dance Floor: HIStory in the Mix">
        Blood on the Dance Floor: HIStory in the Mix
       </a>
      </i>
      , which contained remixes of hit singles from
      <i>
       HIStory
      </i>
      and five new songs. Worldwide sales stand at
      <span class="nowrap">
       6 million
      </span>
      copies, it is the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_remix_albums" title="List of best-selling remix albums">
       best selling remix album ever released
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rojek_206-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rojek-206">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        206
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It reached number one in the UK, as did the
      <a href="/wiki/Blood_on_the_Dance_Floor_(song)" title="Blood on the Dance Floor (song)">
       title track
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rojek_206-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rojek-206">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        206
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6101_207-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6101-207">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        207
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the US, the album was certified platinum, but only reached number 24.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_148-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Certifications-148">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        148
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Forbes placed his annual income at $35 million in 1996 and $20 million in 1997.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finances_139-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Finances-139">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        139
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Throughout June 1999, Jackson was involved in a number of charitable events. He joined
      <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">
       Luciano Pavarotti
      </a>
      for a
      <a href="/wiki/Benefit_concert" title="Benefit concert">
       benefit concert
      </a>
      in Modena, Italy. The show was in support of the nonprofit organization
      <a href="/wiki/War_Child_(charity)" title="War Child (charity)">
       War Child
      </a>
      , and raised a million dollars for the
      <a href="/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia" title="NATO bombing of Yugoslavia">
       refugees of Kosovo, FR Yugoslavia
      </a>
      , as well as additional funds for the children of Guatemala.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
       <a href="#cite_note-208">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        208
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Later that month, Jackson organized a set of "Michael Jackson &amp; Friends" benefit concerts in Germany and Korea. Other artists involved included
      <a href="/wiki/Slash_(musician)" title="Slash (musician)">
       Slash
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scorpions_(band)" title="Scorpions (band)">
       The Scorpions
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Boyz_II_Men" title="Boyz II Men">
       Boyz II Men
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Luther_Vandross" title="Luther Vandross">
       Luther Vandross
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">
       Mariah Carey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/A._R._Rahman" title="A. R. Rahman">
       A. R. Rahman
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Prabhu_Deva" title="Prabhu Deva">
       Prabhu Deva Sundaram
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Shobana" title="Shobana">
       Shobana
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli" title="Andrea Bocelli">
       Andrea Bocelli
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Luciano_Pavarotti" title="Luciano Pavarotti">
       Luciano Pavarotti
      </a>
      . The proceeds went to the
      <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela_Children%27s_Fund" title="Nelson Mandela Children's Fund">
       Nelson Mandela Children's Fund
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/International_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Movement" title="International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement">
       Red Cross
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
       UNESCO
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
       <a href="#cite_note-209">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        209
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      From August 1999 through 2000, he lived in New York City at 4
      <a href="/wiki/74th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="74th Street (Manhattan)">
       East 74th Street
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
       <a href="#cite_note-210">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        210
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="2000.E2.80.9303:_Label_dispute_and_Invincible">
       200003: Label dispute and
       <i>
        Invincible
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      At the turn of the century, Jackson won an American Music Award as Artist of the 1980s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTV_211-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MTV-211">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        211
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Throughout 2000 and 2001, Jackson worked in the studio with Teddy Riley and
      <a href="/wiki/Rodney_Jerkins" title="Rodney Jerkins">
       Rodney Jerkins
      </a>
      , as well as other collaborators. These sessions would result in the album
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Invincible_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Invincible (Michael Jackson album)">
        Invincible
       </a>
      </i>
      , released in October 2001.
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      was Jackson's first full-length album in six years, and it would be the last album of new material he released while still alive. The release of the album was preceded by a dispute between Jackson and his record label,
      <a href="/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment" title="Sony Music Entertainment">
       Sony Music Entertainment
      </a>
      . Jackson had expected the licenses to the masters of his albums to revert to him sometime in the early 2000s. Once he had the licenses, he would be able to promote the material however he pleased and keep all the profits. However, due to various clauses in the contract, the revert date turned out to be many years away. Jackson discovered that the attorney who represented him in the deal was also representing Sony.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6101_207-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6101-207">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        207
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson was also concerned about the fact that for a number of years, Sony had been pressuring him to sell his share in their music catalog venture. Jackson feared that Sony might have a conflict of interest, since if Jackson's career failed, he would have to sell his share of the catalog at a low price.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6147_212-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6147-212">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        212
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson sought an early exit from his contract.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6101_207-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6101-207">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        207
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In September 2001, two
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_30th_Anniversary_Special" title="Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Special">
       30th Anniversary concerts
      </a>
      were held at Madison Square Garden to mark the singer's 30th year as a solo artist. Jackson appeared onstage alongside his brothers for the first time since 1984. The show also featured performances by
      <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BDa" title="Ma">
       Ma
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Usher_(singer)" title="Usher (singer)">
       Usher
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Houston" title="Whitney Houston">
       Whitney Houston
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/NSYNC" title="NSYNC">
       NSYNC
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">
       Destiny's Child
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Monica_(singer)" title="Monica (singer)">
       Monica
      </a>
      , Luther Vandross, and Slash, among other artists.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G503_213-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G503-213">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        213
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The second of the two shows took place the night before the
      <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">
       September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
       <a href="#cite_note-214">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        214
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      After 9/11, Jackson helped organize the
      <a href="/wiki/United_We_Stand:_What_More_Can_I_Give" title="United We Stand: What More Can I Give">
       United We Stand: What More Can I Give
      </a>
      benefit concert at
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Memorial_Stadium" title="Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium">
       RFK Stadium
      </a>
      in Washington, D.C. The concert took place on October 21, 2001, and included performances from dozens of major artists, including Jackson, who performed his song "
      <a href="/wiki/What_More_Can_I_Give" title="What More Can I Give">
       What More Can I Give
      </a>
      " as the finale.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6147_212-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6147-212">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        212
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's solo performances were omitted from the televised version of the benefit concert, although he could still be seen singing background vocals. This omission happened because of contractual issues related to the earlier 30th Anniversary concerts: those concerts were boiled down into a two-hour TV special titled
      <i>
