       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_30th_Anniversary_Special" title="Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Special">
        Michael Jackson: 30th Anniversary Celebration
       </a>
      </i>
      which debuted in November 2001.
     </p>
     <p>
      In spite of the events preceding its release,
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      came out in October 2001 to much anticipation.
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      proved to be a hit, debuting atop the charts in 13 countries and going on to sell approximately 13 million copies worldwide. It received double-platinum certification in the U.S.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_148-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Certifications-148">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        148
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_150-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Achievements-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the sales for
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      were lower than those of his previous releases, due in part to a lack of promotion, no supporting world tour and the label dispute. The album also came out at a bad time for the music industry in general.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6147_212-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6147-212">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        212
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The album cost
      <span class="nowrap">
       $30 million
      </span>
      to record, not including promotional expenditures.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burkeman_215-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Burkeman-215">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        215
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      spawned three singles, "
      <a href="/wiki/You_Rock_My_World" title="You Rock My World">
       You Rock My World
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Cry_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Cry (Michael Jackson song)">
       Cry
      </a>
      ", and "
      <a href="/wiki/Butterflies_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Butterflies (Michael Jackson song)">
       Butterflies
      </a>
      ", the latter without a music video. Jackson alleged in July 2002 that the-then Sony Music chairman
      <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Mottola" title="Tommy Mottola">
       Tommy Mottola
      </a>
      was a "devil" and a "racist" who did not support his African-American artists, using them merely for his own personal gain.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6147_212-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6147-212">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        212
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He charged that Mottola had called his colleague
      <a href="/wiki/Irv_Gotti" title="Irv Gotti">
       Irv Gotti
      </a>
      a "fat
      <a href="/wiki/Nigger" title="Nigger">
       nigger
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
       <a href="#cite_note-216">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        216
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sony refused to renew Jackson's contract, and claimed that a
      <span class="nowrap">
       $25 million
      </span>
      promotional campaign had failed because Jackson refused to tour in the United States.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Burkeman_215-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Burkeman-215">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        215
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2002, Michael Jackson won his 22nd American Music Award for Artist of the Century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
       <a href="#cite_note-217">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        217
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the same year, Jackson's third child, Prince Michael Jackson II (nicknamed "Blanket") was born.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        218
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The mother's identity was not announced, but Jackson has said the child was the result of
      <a href="/wiki/Artificial_insemination" title="Artificial insemination">
       artificial insemination
      </a>
      from a
      <a href="/wiki/Surrogacy" title="Surrogacy">
       surrogate mother
      </a>
      and his own sperm.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T599600_204-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T599600-204">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        204
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On November 20 of that year, Jackson brought his infant son onto the balcony of his room at the
      <a href="/wiki/Hotel_Adlon" title="Hotel Adlon">
       Hotel Adlon
      </a>
      in Berlin, as fans stood below, holding him in his right arm, with a cloth loosely draped over the baby's face. The baby was briefly extended over a railing, four stories above ground level, causing widespread criticism in the media. Jackson later apologized for the incident, calling it "a terrible mistake".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        219
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sony released
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Number_Ones_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Number Ones (Michael Jackson album)">
        Number Ones
       </a>
      </i>
      , a compilation of Jackson's hits on CD and DVD. In the U.S., the album was certified triple platinum by the RIAA; in the UK it was certified six times platinum for shipments of at least 1.2 million units.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Certifications_148-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Certifications-148">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        148
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        220
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="2003.E2.80.9305:_Second_child_sexual_abuse_allegations_and_acquittal">
       200305: Second child sexual abuse allegations and acquittal
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Living_with_Michael_Jackson" title="Living with Michael Jackson">
       Living with Michael Jackson
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">
       Trial of Michael Jackson
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="406" data-file-width="449" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg/220px-Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg/330px-Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg/440px-Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_in_Vegas_cropped-2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson in Las Vegas, 2003.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Beginning in May 2002, Jackson allowed a documentary film crew, led by British TV personality
      <a href="/wiki/Martin_Bashir" title="Martin Bashir">
       Martin Bashir
      </a>
      , to follow him around nearly everywhere he went. Bashir's film crew was with Jackson during the "baby-dangling incident" in Berlin. The program was broadcast in March 2003 as
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Living_with_Michael_Jackson" title="Living with Michael Jackson">
        Living with Michael Jackson
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In a particularly controversial scene, Jackson was seen holding hands and discussing sleeping arrangements with a young boy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T640_221-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-T640-221">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        221
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As soon as the documentary aired, the Santa Barbara county attorney's office began a criminal investigation. After an initial probe from the
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Police_Department" title="Los Angeles Police Department">
       LAPD
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Child_Protective_Services" title="Child Protective Services">
       DCFS
      </a>
      was conducted in February 2003, they had initially concluded that molestation allegations were "unfounded" at the time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SG2003_185-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SG2003-185">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        185
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the young boy involved in the documentary and his mother later told investigators that Jackson had been improper with the boy, Jackson was arrested in November 2003, and was charged with seven counts of child molestation and two counts of
      <a href="/wiki/Alcoholic_beverage#United_States_of_America" title="Alcoholic beverage">
       administering an intoxicating agent
      </a>
      in relation to the 13-year-old boy shown in the film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T640_221-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T640-221">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        221
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson denied the allegations, saying the sleepovers were not sexual in nature. The
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Trial of Michael Jackson">
        People v. Jackson
       </a>
      </i>
      trial began on January 31, 2005, in
      <a href="/wiki/Santa_Maria,_California" title="Santa Maria, California">
       Santa Maria
      </a>
      , California, and lasted five months, until the end of May. On June 13, 2005, Jackson was acquitted on all counts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
       <a href="#cite_note-222">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        222
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
       <a href="#cite_note-223">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        223
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
       <a href="#cite_note-224">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        224
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the trial, in a highly publicized relocation he moved to the Persian Gulf island of
      <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">
       Bahrain
      </a>
      , as a guest of
      <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_bin_Hamad_bin_Isa_Al_Khalifa" title="Abdullah bin Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa">
       Sheikh Abdullah
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
       <a href="#cite_note-225">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        225
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Bahrain was also where the family intended to send Jackson if he was convicted (though Jackson did not know about the plan), according to a statement by Jermaine Jackson printed in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">
        The Times
       </a>
      </i>
      of London in September 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
       <a href="#cite_note-226">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        226
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="2006.E2.80.9309:_Closure_of_Neverland.2C_final_years.2C_and_This_Is_It">
       200609: Closure of Neverland, final years, and
       <i>
        This Is It
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1089" data-file-width="663" height="279" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_2006.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson and his son Blanket in
        <a href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">
         Disneyland Paris
        </a>
        , 2006.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In March 2006, the main house at the Neverland Ranch was closed as a cost-cutting measure.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        227
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      There were numerous reports around that time that Jackson was having financial problems. Jackson had been delinquent on his repayments of a $270 million loan secured against his music publishing holdings, even though those holdings were reportedly making him as much as
      <span class="nowrap">
       $75 million
      </span>
      a year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        228
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_America" title="Bank of America">
       Bank of America
      </a>
      sold the debt to
      <a href="/wiki/Fortress_Investment_Group" title="Fortress Investment Group">
       Fortress Investments
      </a>
      . Sony reportedly proposed a restructuring deal which would give them a future option to buy half of Jackson's stake in their jointly owned publishing company (leaving Jackson with a 25% stake).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sonydeal_195-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-sonydeal-195">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        195
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson agreed to a Sony-backed refinancing deal in April 2006, although the exact details were not made public.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
       <a href="#cite_note-229">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        229
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson did not have a recording contract in place with Sony or any other major record label at the time.
     </p>
     <p>
      In early 2006, there was an announcement that Jackson had signed a contract with a
      <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">
       Bahrain
      </a>
      -based startup called Two Seas Records. However, nothing ever came of that deal, and the CEO of Two Seas,
      <a href="/wiki/Gut_Records" title="Gut Records">
       Guy Holmes
      </a>
      , later stated that the deal had never been finalized.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        230
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bahrain_231-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bahrain-231">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        231
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Throughout 2006, Sony repackaged 20 singles from the 1980s and 1990s as the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Visionary:_The_Video_Singles" title="Visionary: The Video Singles">
        Michael Jackson: Visionary
       </a>
      </i>
      series, which subsequently became a
      <a href="/wiki/Box_set" title="Box set">
       box set
      </a>
      . Most of those singles returned to the charts as a result. In September 2006, Jackson and his ex-wife Debbie Rowe confirmed reports that they had settled their long-running child custody suit. The terms were never made public. Jackson continued to be the custodial parent of the couple's two children.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ex_wife_205-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ex_wife-205">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        205
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In October 2006,
      <a href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">
       Fox News
      </a>
      entertainment reporter Roger Friedman said that Jackson had been recording at a studio in rural
      <a href="/wiki/County_Westmeath" title="County Westmeath">
       Westmeath, Ireland
      </a>
      . It was not known at the time what Jackson might be working on, or who might be paying for the sessions, since his publicist had recently issued a statement claiming that he had left Two Seas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bahrain_231-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bahrain-231">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        231
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        232
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In November 2006, Jackson invited an
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Access_Hollywood" title="Access Hollywood">
        Access Hollywood
       </a>
      </i>
      camera crew into the studio in Westmeath, and
      <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">
       MSNBC
      </a>
      broke the story that he was working on a new album, produced by
      <a href="/wiki/Will.i.am" title="Will.i.am">
       will.i.am
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/The_Black_Eyed_Peas" title="The Black Eyed Peas">
       the Black Eyed Peas
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_150-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Achievements-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson performed at the
      <a href="/wiki/2006_World_Music_Awards" title="2006 World Music Awards">
       World Music Awards
      </a>
      , in London on November 15, 2006, and accepted a Diamond Award for selling over
      <span class="nowrap">
       100 million
      </span>
      records.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_150-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Achievements-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        233
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson returned to the United States after Christmas 2006 to attend
      <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">
       James Brown
      </a>
      's funeral in
      <a href="/wiki/Augusta,_Georgia" title="Augusta, Georgia">
       Augusta
      </a>
      , Georgia. He gave one of the eulogies, saying that "James Brown is my greatest inspiration."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
       <a href="#cite_note-234">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        234
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the spring of 2007, Jackson and Sony teamed up to buy yet another music publishing company:
      <a href="/wiki/Famous_Music" title="Famous Music">
       Famous Music LLC
      </a>
      , formerly owned by
      <a href="/wiki/Viacom" title="Viacom">
       Viacom
      </a>
      . This deal gave him the rights to songs by
      <a href="/wiki/Eminem" title="Eminem">
       Eminem
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Shakira" title="Shakira">
       Shakira
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Beck" title="Beck">
       Beck
      </a>
      , among others.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
       <a href="#cite_note-235">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        235
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson recorded extensively during this period in New York with songwriter and producer will.i.am and also in
      <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley" title="Las Vegas Valley">
       Las Vegas
      </a>
      with producers
      <a href="/wiki/Akon" title="Akon">
       Akon
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/RedOne" title="RedOne">
       RedOne
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        236
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
       <a href="#cite_note-237">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        237
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In March 2007, Jackson gave a brief interview to the
      <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">
       Associated Press
      </a>
      in Tokyo, where he said, "I've been in the entertainment industry since I was 6 years old, and as
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">
       Charles Dickens
      </a>
      would say, 'It's been the best of times, the worst of times.' But I would not change my career..... While some have made deliberate attempts to hurt me, I take it in stride because I have a loving family, a strong faith and wonderful friends and fans who have, and continue, to support me."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        238
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In March 2007, Jackson visited a U.S. Army post in Japan named
      <a href="/wiki/Camp_Zama" title="Camp Zama">
       Camp Zama
      </a>
      to greet 3,000 plus U.S. troops and their families. The hosts presented Jackson with a Certificate of Appreciation for his devotion to U.S. Military troops and their families.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        239
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In September 2007, Jackson was reportedly still working with will.i.am, but the album was apparently never completed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        240
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, in 2008, Jackson and Sony released
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Thriller_25" title="Thriller 25">
        Thriller 25
       </a>
      </i>
      to mark the 25th anniversary of the original
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Thriller (Michael Jackson album)">
        Thriller
       </a>
      </i>
      . This album featured the previously unreleased song "For All Time" (an outtake from the original sessions) as well as remixes, where Jackson collaborated with younger artists who had been inspired by his work.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_25_241-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Thriller_25-241">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        241
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Two of the remixes were released as singles with only modest success: "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Girl_Is_Mine_2008" title="The Girl Is Mine 2008">
       The Girl Is Mine 2008
      </a>
      " (with
      <a href="/wiki/Will.i.am" title="Will.i.am">
       will.i.am
      </a>
      ) and "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wanna_Be_Startin%27_Somethin%27_2008" title="Wanna Be Startin' Somethin' 2008">
       Wanna Be Startin' Somethin' 2008
      </a>
      " (with
      <a href="/wiki/Akon" title="Akon">
       Akon
      </a>
      ). The first single was based on an early demo version, without
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">
       Paul McCartney
      </a>
      . The album itself was a hit, however.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_25_241-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Thriller_25-241">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        241
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
       <a href="#cite_note-242">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        242
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
       <a href="#cite_note-243">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        243
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
       <a href="#cite_note-244">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        244
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In anticipation of Jackson's 50th birthday, Sony BMG released a series of greatest-hits albums called
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/King_of_Pop_(album)" title="King of Pop (album)">
        King of Pop
       </a>
      </i>
      . Slightly different versions were released in various countries, based on polls of local fans.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
       <a href="#cite_note-245">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        245
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       King of Pop
      </i>
      reached the top 10 in most countries where it was issued, and also sold well as an import in other countries (such as the United States).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        246
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
       <a href="#cite_note-247">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        247
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NeverlandRides.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="550" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/NeverlandRides.jpg/220px-NeverlandRides.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/NeverlandRides.jpg/330px-NeverlandRides.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/NeverlandRides.jpg/440px-NeverlandRides.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NeverlandRides.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        An aerial view of part of Jackson's 2,800-acre (11 km
        <sup>
         2
        </sup>
        ) Neverland Valley Ranch near Los Olivos, California, showing the many rides.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In late 2008, Fortress Investments threatened to foreclose on
      <a href="/wiki/Neverland_Ranch" title="Neverland Ranch">
       Neverland Ranch
      </a>
      , which Jackson used as collateral for loans running into many tens of millions of dollars. However, Fortress opted to sell Jackson's debts to
      <a href="/wiki/Colony_Capital" title="Colony Capital">
       Colony Capital LLC
      </a>
      . In November, Jackson transferred Neverland Ranch's title to Sycamore Valley Ranch Company LLC, which was a joint venture between Jackson and Colony Capital LLC. This deal cleared Jackson's debt, and he reportedly even gained an extra
      <span class="nowrap">
       $35 million
      </span>
      from the venture. At the time of his death, Jackson still owned a stake in Neverland/Sycamore Valley, but it was not announced how large that stake was.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
       <a href="#cite_note-248">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        248
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
       <a href="#cite_note-249">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        249
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In September 2008, Jackson entered negotiations with
      <a href="/wiki/Julien%27s_Auctions" title="Julien's Auctions">
       Julien's Auction House
      </a>
      to display and auction a large collection of memorabilia amounting to approximately 1,390 lots. The auction was scheduled to take place between April 22 and 25.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
       <a href="#cite_note-250">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        250
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      An exhibition of the lots opened as scheduled on April 14, but the actual auction was eventually cancelled at Jackson's request.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        251
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In March 2009, Jackson held a press conference at London's
      <a href="/wiki/The_O2_Arena" title="The O2 Arena">
       O
       <sub>
        2
       </sub>
       Arena
      </a>
      and announced a series of comeback concerts titled
      <a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(concerts)" title="This Is It (concerts)">
       This Is It
      </a>
      . The shows would be Jackson's first major series of concerts since the HIStory World Tour finished in 1997. Jackson suggested possible retirement after the shows; he said it would be his "final curtain call". The initial plan was for 10 concerts in London, followed by shows in Paris, New York City and
      <a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">
       Mumbai
      </a>
      . Randy Phillips, president and chief executive of AEG Live, stated that the first 10 dates alone would earn the singer approximately 50 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
       <a href="#cite_note-252">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        252
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The London residency was increased to 50 dates after record breaking ticket sales: over one million were sold in less than two hours.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        253
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson rehearsed in Los Angeles in the weeks leading up to the tour under the direction of choreographer
      <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Ortega" title="Kenny Ortega">
       Kenny Ortega
      </a>
      . Most of these rehearsals took place at the
      <a href="/wiki/Staples_Center" title="Staples Center">
       Staples Center
      </a>
      , which was owned by AEG.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        254
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The concerts would have commenced on July 13, 2009, and finished on March 6, 2010. Less than three weeks before the first show was due to begin in London and with all concerts being sold out, Jackson died after suffering cardiac arrest.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        255
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some time before his death, it was reported that he was starting a clothing line with
      <a href="/wiki/Christian_Audigier" title="Christian Audigier">
       Christian Audigier
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        256
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
       <a href="#cite_note-257">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        257
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Jackson's first posthumous song released entirely by his Estate was titled "
      <a href="/wiki/This_Is_It_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="This Is It (Michael Jackson song)">
       This Is It
      </a>
      " which Jackson cowrote in the 1980s with
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_Anka" title="Paul Anka">
       Paul Anka
      </a>
      . It was not on the set lists for the concerts, and the recording was based on an old demo tape. The surviving brothers reunited in the studio for the first time since 1989 to record backing vocals. On October 28, 2009, a documentary film about the rehearsals titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_This_Is_It" title="Michael Jackson's This Is It">
        Michael Jackson's This Is It
       </a>
      </i>
      was released.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
       <a href="#cite_note-258">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        258
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even though it ran for a limited two-week engagement, it became the highest grossing documentary or concert movie of all time, with earnings of more than
      <span class="nowrap">
       $260 million
      </span>
      worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
       <a href="#cite_note-259">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        259
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's estate received 90% of the profits.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
       <a href="#cite_note-260">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        260
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The film was accompanied by a
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_This_Is_It_(album)" title="Michael Jackson's This Is It (album)">
       compilation album of the same name
      </a>
      . Two versions of the new song appear on the album, which also featured original masters of Jackson's hits in the order in which they appear in the movie, along with a bonus disc with previously unreleased versions of more Jackson hits as well as a spoken-word poem titled "Planet Earth".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        261
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Awards_of_2009" title="American Music Awards of 2009">
       2009 American Music Awards
      </a>
      , Jackson won four posthumous awards, two for him and two for his album
      <i>
       Number Ones
      </i>
      , bringing his total American Music Awards to 26.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
       <a href="#cite_note-262">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        262
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
       <a href="#cite_note-263">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        263
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Death_and_memorial">
       Death and memorial
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Death of Michael Jackson">
       Death of Michael Jackson
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_memorial_service" title="Michael Jackson memorial service">
       Michael Jackson memorial service
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG">
        <img alt="Jackson's Star with flowers and notes on it" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3168" data-file-width="4752" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/220px-Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/330px-Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/440px-Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Fans flocked to Jackson's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, adorning it with flowers and notes on the day of his death.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      On June 25, 2009, Jackson died while lying in his bed at his rented mansion at 100 North Carolwood Drive in the
      <a href="/wiki/Holmby_Hills,_Los_Angeles" title="Holmby Hills, Los Angeles">
       Holmby Hills
      </a>
      district of
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">
       Los Angeles
      </a>
      . Attempts at resuscitating him by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trial_of_Conrad_Murray" title="Trial of Conrad Murray">
       Conrad Murray
      </a>
      , his
      <a href="/wiki/Concierge_medicine" title="Concierge medicine">
       personal physician
      </a>
      , were unsuccessful.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times_264-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Times-264">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        264
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Fire_Department" title="Los Angeles Fire Department">
       Los Angeles Fire Department
      </a>
      paramedics received a
      <a href="/wiki/9-1-1" title="9-1-1">
       911
      </a>
      call at 12:22 (
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Time_Zone" title="Pacific Time Zone">
       PDT
      </a>
      , 19:22 UTC), arriving three minutes later at Jackson's location.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        265
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        266
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He was reportedly not breathing and
      <a href="/wiki/Cardiopulmonary_resuscitation" title="Cardiopulmonary resuscitation">
       CPR
      </a>
      was performed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
       <a href="#cite_note-267">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        267
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Resuscitation efforts continued en route to the
      <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_UCLA_Medical_Center" title="Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center">
       Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center
      </a>
      , and for more than an hour after arriving there at 1:13 (20:13 UTC). He was pronounced dead at 2:26 local time (21:26 UTC).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        268
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        269
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's death triggered a global outpouring of grief.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times_264-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Times-264">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        264
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The news spread quickly online, causing websites to slow down and
      <a href="/wiki/Crash_(computing)" title="Crash (computing)">
       crash
      </a>
      from user overload. Both
      <a href="/wiki/TMZ" title="TMZ">
       TMZ
      </a>
      and the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" title="Los Angeles Times">
        Los Angeles Times
       </a>
      </i>
      suffered outages.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
       <a href="#cite_note-270">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        270
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">
       Google
      </a>
      initially believed that the input from millions of people searching for "Michael Jackson" meant that the search engine was under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Distributed_denial-of-service_attack" title="Distributed denial-of-service attack">
       DDoS attack
      </a>
      , and blocked searches related to Michael Jackson for 30 minutes. Twitter reported a crash, as did Wikipedia at
      <span class="nowrap">
       3:15 pm
      </span>
      PDT (22:15 UTC).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
       <a href="#cite_note-271">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        271
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Wikimedia_Foundation" title="Wikimedia Foundation">
       Wikimedia Foundation
      </a>
      reported nearly a million visitors to Jackson's biography within one hour, probably the most visitors in a one-hour period to any article in Wikipedia's history.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        272
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/AOL_Instant_Messenger" title="AOL Instant Messenger">
       AOL Instant Messenger
      </a>
      collapsed for 40 minutes. AOL called it a "seminal moment in Internet history", adding, "We've never seen anything like it in terms of scope or depth."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        273
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Around 15% of Twitter postsor 5,000
      <a class="extiw" href="//en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tweet#Noun" title="wikt:tweet">
       tweets
      </a>
      per minutereportedly mentioned Jackson after the news broke,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-crash_274-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-crash-274">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        274
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wortham_275-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wortham-275">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        275
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      compared to the 5% recalled as having mentioned the
      <a href="/wiki/Iranian_presidential_election,_2009" title="Iranian presidential election, 2009">
       Iranian elections
      </a>
      or the
      <a href="/wiki/2009_flu_pandemic" title="2009 flu pandemic">
       flu pandemic
      </a>
      that had made headlines earlier in the year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wortham_275-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wortham-275">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        275
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Overall,
      <a href="/wiki/Web_traffic" title="Web traffic">
       web traffic
      </a>
      ranged from 11% to at least 20% higher than normal.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-crash_274-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-crash-274">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        274
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
       <a href="#cite_note-276">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        276
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">
       MTV
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/BET" title="BET">
       BET
      </a>
      aired
      <a href="/wiki/Marathon_(media)" title="Marathon (media)">
       marathons
      </a>
      of Jackson's music videos.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
       <a href="#cite_note-277">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        277
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson specials aired on multiple television stations around the world. The British soap opera
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">
        EastEnders
       </a>
      </i>
      added a last-minute scene, in which one character tells another about the news, to the June 26 episode.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
       <a href="#cite_note-278">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        278
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="2448" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg/220px-Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg/330px-Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg/440px-Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Grave.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson's tomb in the Holly Terrace of the Great Mausoleum, Forest Lawn Glendale.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Jackson's memorial was held on July 7, 2009, at the
      <a href="/wiki/Staples_Center" title="Staples Center">
       Staples Center
      </a>
      in Los Angeles, preceded by a private family service at
      <a href="/wiki/Forest_Lawn_Memorial_Park,_Hollywood_Hills#Court_of_Liberty" title="Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Hollywood Hills">
       Forest Lawn Memorial Park's Hall of Liberty
      </a>
      . Because of the high demand, organizers of the service fashioned a lottery style distribution method to give out tickets to members of the public. Applications were submitted by 1.6 million fans for tickets to the service over the two-day period that registration was open. A total of 8,750 names were drawn at random to decide who to distribute tickets to, with each recipient receiving two tickets each.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        279
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's casket was present during the memorial but no information was released about the final disposition of the body. The memorial service was one of the most watched events in online streaming history.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
       <a href="#cite_note-280">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        280
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The U.S. audience was estimated by Nielsen to be 31.1 million, an amount comparable to the estimated
      <span class="nowrap">
       35.1 million
      </span>
      that watched the
      <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Ronald_Reagan" title="Death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan">
       2004 burial of former president Ronald Reagan
      </a>
      , and the estimated
      <span class="nowrap">
       33.1 million
      </span>
      Americans who watched the
      <a href="/wiki/Funeral_of_Diana,_Princess_of_Wales" title="Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales">
       1997 funeral for Princess Diana
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
       <a href="#cite_note-281">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        281
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">
       Mariah Carey
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Stevie_Wonder" title="Stevie Wonder">
       Stevie Wonder
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lionel_Richie" title="Lionel Richie">
       Lionel Richie
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/John_Mayer" title="John Mayer">
       John Mayer
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Hudson" title="Jennifer Hudson">
       Jennifer Hudson
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Usher_(singer)" title="Usher (singer)">
       Usher
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">
       Jermaine Jackson
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Shaheen_Jafargholi" title="Shaheen Jafargholi">
       Shaheen Jafargholi
      </a>
      performed at the event.
      <a href="/wiki/Berry_Gordy" title="Berry Gordy">
       Berry Gordy
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Smokey_Robinson" title="Smokey Robinson">
       Smokey Robinson
      </a>
      gave eulogies, while
      <a href="/wiki/Queen_Latifah" title="Queen Latifah">
       Queen Latifah
      </a>
      read "We had him", a poem written for the occasion by
      <a href="/wiki/Maya_Angelou" title="Maya Angelou">
       Maya Angelou
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
       <a href="#cite_note-282">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        282
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Reverend
      <a href="/wiki/Al_Sharpton" title="Al Sharpton">
       Al Sharpton
      </a>
      received a standing ovation with cheers when he told Jackson's children, "Wasn't nothing strange about your daddy. It was strange what your daddy had to deal with. But he dealt with it anyway."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
       <a href="#cite_note-283">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        283
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The memorial is best remembered for when Jackson's 11-year-old daughter, Paris Katherine, speaking publicly for the first time cried as she told the crowd, "Ever since I was born, Daddy has been the best father you could ever imagine..... I just wanted to say I love him..... so much."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
       <a href="#cite_note-284">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        284
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
       <a href="#cite_note-285">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        285
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Reverend Lucious Smith provided a closing prayer.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
       <a href="#cite_note-286">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        286
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On August 24, several news outlets quoted anonymous sources as stating that the Los Angeles coroner had decided to treat Jackson's death as a homicide; this was later confirmed by the coroner on August 28.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
       <a href="#cite_note-287">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        287
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
       <a href="#cite_note-288">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        288
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the time of death, Jackson had been administered
      <a href="/wiki/Propofol" title="Propofol">
       propofol
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lorazepam" title="Lorazepam">
       lorazepam
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Midazolam" title="Midazolam">
       midazolam
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
       <a href="#cite_note-289">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        289
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Law enforcement officials conducted a manslaughter investigation of his personal physician Conrad Murray, who
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trial_of_Conrad_Murray" title="Trial of Conrad Murray">
       was charged
      </a>
      with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Involuntary_manslaughter" title="Involuntary manslaughter">
       involuntary manslaughter
      </a>
      by prosecutors in Los Angeles on February 8, 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
       <a href="#cite_note-290">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        290
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's body was entombed on September 3, 2009, at
      <a href="/wiki/Forest_Lawn_Memorial_Park_(Glendale)" title="Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)">
       Forest Lawn Memorial Park
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Glendale,_California" title="Glendale, California">
       Glendale, California
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
       <a href="#cite_note-291">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        291
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Forest_Lawn2010.jpg">
        <img alt="Portrait and other tributes, including mural and messages from 650 Spanish fans, letters, pictures, teddy bears, and flowers." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2672" data-file-width="4000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Forest_Lawn2010.jpg/220px-Forest_Lawn2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Forest_Lawn2010.jpg/330px-Forest_Lawn2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Forest_Lawn2010.jpg/440px-Forest_Lawn2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Forest_Lawn2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Tribute of fans from all over the world in the Forest Lawn Memorial Park on the first anniversary of his death.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      On June 25, 2010, the first anniversary of Jackson's death, fans traveled to Los Angeles to pay their tribute to him. They visited Jackson's star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame and his family's home, as well as Forest Lawn Memorial Park. Many of the fans were carrying sunflowers and other tribute items to drop off at the sites. Members of the Jackson family and close friends arrived to pay their respects.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
       <a href="#cite_note-292">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        292
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        293
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Katherine returned to Gary, Indiana to unveil a granite monument constructed in the front yard of the family home. The memorial continued with a candlelight vigil and a special performance of "We Are the World".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        294
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        295
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On June 26, there was a protest march in front of the Los Angeles Police Department's Robbery-Homicide Division at the old Parker Center building and a petition with thousands of signatures demanding justice was delivered.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        296
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
       <a href="#cite_note-297">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        297
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Jackson Family Foundation in conjunction with Voiceplate presented "Forever Michael", an event bringing together Jackson family members, celebrities, fans, supporters and the community to celebrate and honor his legacy. A portion of the proceeds were presented to some of Jackson's favorite charities. Katherine also introduced her new book "Never Can Say Goodbye".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
       <a href="#cite_note-298">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        298
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
       <a href="#cite_note-299">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        299
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
       <a href="#cite_note-300">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        300
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Aftermath">
       Aftermath
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      After his death, Jackson became the best-selling albums artist of 2009. He sold over 8.2 million albums in the United States, and a total of 35 million albums worldwide, in the 12 months that followed his death.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swift-Boyle_301-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Swift-Boyle-301">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        301
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
       <a href="#cite_note-302">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        302
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson became the first artist to sell one million downloads in a week in download history, with a record-breaking 2.6 million downloads of his songs. After his death, three of his albums sold more than any new album, which was the first time a catalog album has ever scanned more sales than any new album.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
       <a href="#cite_note-303">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        303
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson also became the first artist in history to have four of the top 20 best selling albums in a single year in the United States.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swift-Boyle_301-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Swift-Boyle-301">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        301
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following this surge in sales, Sony announced that they had extended their relationship with his material. The distribution rights held by Sony Music were due to expire in 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sony_304-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sony-304">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        304
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On March 16, 2010, Sony Music Entertainment, in a move spearheaded by its
      <a href="/wiki/Columbia/Epic_Label_Group" title="Columbia/Epic Label Group">
       Columbia/Epic Label Group
      </a>
      division, signed a new deal with the Jackson estate to extend their distribution rights to his back catalogue until at least 2017, as well as to obtain permission to release ten new albums with previously unreleased material and new collections of released work.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
       <a href="#cite_note-305">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        305
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On November 4, 2010, Sony announced the release of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_(album)" title="Michael (album)">
        Michael
       </a>
      </i>
      , the first posthumous album set to be released on December 14, with the promotional single released to the radios on November 8, titled "
      <a href="/wiki/Breaking_News_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Breaking News (Michael Jackson song)">
       Breaking News
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
       <a href="#cite_note-306">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        306
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The deal was unprecedented in the music industry as it is the most expensive music contract pertaining to a single artist in history; it reportedly involved Sony Music paying
      <span class="nowrap">
       $250 million
      </span>
      for the deal, with the Jackson estate getting the full sum as well as its share of royalties for all works released.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sony_304-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sony-304">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        304
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
       <a href="#cite_note-307">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        307
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Video game developer
      <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft" title="Ubisoft">
       Ubisoft
      </a>
      announced it would release a new
      <a href="/wiki/Music_video_game" title="Music video game">
       dancing-and-singing game
      </a>
      featuring Michael Jackson for the 2010 holiday season. The game titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_The_Experience" title="Michael Jackson: The Experience">
        Michael Jackson: The Experience
       </a>
      </i>
      was among the first to use
      <a href="/wiki/Kinect" title="Kinect">
       Kinect
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_Move" title="PlayStation Move">
       PlayStation Move
      </a>
      , the respective motion-detecting camera systems for Microsoft's
      <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">
       Xbox 360
      </a>
      and Sony's
      <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">
       PlayStation 3
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
       <a href="#cite_note-308">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        308
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On November 3, 2010, the theatrical performing company
      <a href="/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil" title="Cirque du Soleil">
       Cirque du Soleil
      </a>
      announced that it would launch
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_The_Immortal_World_Tour" title="Michael Jackson: The Immortal World Tour">
        Michael Jackson: The Immortal World Tour
       </a>
      </i>
      in October 2011 in Montreal, while a permanent show will reside in Las Vegas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
       <a href="#cite_note-309">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        309
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 90-minute $57-million production will combine Jackson's iconic musical oeuvre and choreography with the Cirque's signature artistry, dance and aerial displays involving 65 artists.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
       <a href="#cite_note-310">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        310
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The tour was written and directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Jamie_King" title="Jamie King">
       Jamie King
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
       <a href="#cite_note-311">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        311
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and centers on Jackson's "inspirational Giving Tree  the wellspring of creativity where his love of music and dance, fairy tale and magic, and the fragile beauty of nature are unlocked."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
       <a href="#cite_note-312">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        312
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On October 3, 2011, the accompanying compilation soundtrack album
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Immortal_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Immortal (Michael Jackson album)">
        Immortal
       </a>
      </i>
      was announced to have over 40 Jackson's original recordings re-produced by Kevin Antunes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
       <a href="#cite_note-313">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        313
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A second, larger and more theatrical Cirque show entitled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson:_One" title="Michael Jackson: One">
        Michael Jackson: One
       </a>
      </i>
      designed for residency at the
      <a href="/wiki/Mandalay_Bay" title="Mandalay Bay">
       Mandalay Bay
      </a>
      resort in Las Vegas was announced on February 21, 2013. This show, whose production was written and directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Jamie_King" title="Jamie King">
       Jamie King
      </a>
      who produced the Immortal show, began its run on May 23, 2013 in a newly renovated theater to both critical and commercial success.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
       <a href="#cite_note-314">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        314
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
       <a href="#cite_note-315">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        315
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
       <a href="#cite_note-316">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        316
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
       <a href="#cite_note-317">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        317
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2011, it was revealed that Jackson had recorded in 19811983 with
      <a href="/wiki/Freddie_Mercury" title="Freddie Mercury">
       Freddie Mercury
      </a>
      , including a demo of "
      <a href="/wiki/State_of_Shock_(song)" title="State of Shock (song)">
       State of Shock
      </a>
      ," "Victory" and "There Must Be More to Life Than This."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
       <a href="#cite_note-318">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        318
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      These recordings were originally intended for a full-length album of duets but, according to
      <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">
       Queen
      </a>
      's then-manager,
      <a href="/wiki/Jim_Beach" title="Jim Beach">
       Jim Beach
      </a>
      , the relationship between the two singers soured when Jackson insisted on bringing a
      <a href="/wiki/Llama" title="Llama">
       llama
      </a>
      into the recording studio.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
       <a href="#cite_note-319">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        319
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      None of these collaborations were officially released, although
      <a href="/wiki/Bootleg_recording" title="Bootleg recording">
       bootleg
      </a>
      recordings exist. Jackson went on to record the single "State of Shock" with
      <a href="/wiki/Mick_Jagger" title="Mick Jagger">
       Mick Jagger
      </a>
      for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Jacksons" title="The Jacksons">
       the Jacksons
      </a>
      ' album
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Victory_(The_Jacksons_album)" title="Victory (The Jacksons album)">
        Victory
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
       <a href="#cite_note-320">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        320
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Mercury included the solo version of "There Must Be More To Life Than This" on his
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Mr._Bad_Guy" title="Mr. Bad Guy">
        Mr. Bad Guy
       </a>
      </i>
      album.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
       <a href="#cite_note-321">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        321
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In November 2011, Brian May announced that a series of duets that Mercury recorded with Jackson were to be released in 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
       <a href="#cite_note-322">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        322
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He later updated the release date to autumn of 2013 and then to 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
       <a href="#cite_note-323">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        323
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In April 2011, Jackson's longtime friend and billionaire businessman
      <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Al-Fayed" title="Mohamed Al-Fayed">
       Mohamed Al-Fayed
      </a>
      , chairman of
      <a href="/wiki/Fulham_F.C." title="Fulham F.C.">
       Fulham Football Club
      </a>
      , unveiled a
      <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Statue of Michael Jackson">
       statue of Michael Jackson
      </a>
      outside the club's stadium,
      <a href="/wiki/Craven_Cottage" title="Craven Cottage">
       Craven Cottage
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fulham_324-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fulham-324">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        324
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Fulham fans were bemused by the statue and failed to understand the relevance of Jackson to the club.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
       <a href="#cite_note-325">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        325
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Al Fayed defended the statue and told the fans to "go to hell" if they did not appreciate it.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fulham_324-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fulham-324">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        324
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The statue was removed in September 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
       <a href="#cite_note-326">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        326
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2012, in an attempt to end family public feuding, Jackson's brother
      <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_Jackson" title="Jermaine Jackson">
       Jermaine Jackson
      </a>
      retracted his signature on a letter made public criticizing executors of Michael Jackson's estate and his mother's advisers concerning the legitimacy of his brother's will.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
       <a href="#cite_note-327">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        327
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      T.J. Jackson, son of Tito Jackson, was given co-guardianship of Michael Jackson's children after false reports surfaced of Katherine Jackson going missing.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
       <a href="#cite_note-328">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        328
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On May 16, 2013, choreographer
      <a href="/wiki/Wade_Robson" title="Wade Robson">
       Wade Robson
      </a>
      alleged on
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Today_(U.S._TV_program)" title="Today (U.S. TV program)">
        The Today Show
       </a>
      </i>
      that Jackson "performed sexual acts on me and forced me to perform sexual acts on him" for 7 years, beginning when Robson was 7 years old.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
       <a href="#cite_note-329">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        329
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Robson had previously testified in defence of Jackson at the singer's 2005 child molestation trial.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
       <a href="#cite_note-330">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        330
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The attorney for Jackson's estate described Robson's claim as "outrageous and pathetic".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
       <a href="#cite_note-331">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        331
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The date for the hearing which will determine whether Robson can sue Jackson's estate was scheduled for June 2, 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
       <a href="#cite_note-332">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        332
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In February 2014, the
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service" title="Internal Revenue Service">
       Internal Revenue Service
      </a>
      reported that Jackson's estate owed them $702 million, including $505 million in taxes and $197 million in penalties after they claimed the estate undervalued Jackson's fortune.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gottlieb_333-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Gottlieb-333">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        333
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On March 31, 2014, Epic Records announced that an album of eight songs of unreleased material culled from past recording sessions would be issued under the title,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Xscape_(album)" title="Xscape (album)">
        Xscape
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
       <a href="#cite_note-334">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        334
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was released on May 13, 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
       <a href="#cite_note-335">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        335
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      On May 12, 2014, another young man, Jimmy Safechuck, sued Jackson's estate, claiming Jackson sexually abused him "from the age of 10 to about 14 or 15" in the 1980s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336">
       <a href="#cite_note-336">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        336
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      During the
      <a href="/wiki/2014_Billboard_Music_Awards" title="2014 Billboard Music Awards">
       2014 Billboard Music Awards
      </a>
      on May 18, a "
      <a href="/wiki/Pepper%27s_ghost" title="Pepper's ghost">
       Pepper's ghost
      </a>
      " likeness of Jackson appeared, dancing to "
      <a href="/wiki/Slave_to_the_Rhythm_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Slave to the Rhythm (Michael Jackson song)">
       Slave to the Rhythm
      </a>
      ", one of the tracks from
      <i>
       Xscape
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337">
       <a href="#cite_note-337">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        337
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Artistry">
       Artistry
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">
       Influences
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg">
        <img alt="Silver-colored statue of Jackson standing up with his arms bent inward and both legs spaced apart." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2242" data-file-width="1403" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg/170px-Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg/255px-Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg/340px-Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_sculpture.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        One of many identical statues, based on
        <a href="/wiki/Diana_Walczak" title="Diana Walczak">
         Diana Walczak
        </a>
        's original HIStory statue, positioned throughout Europe to promote
        <i>
         HIStory
        </i>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Jackson had been influenced by the work of musicians such as
      <a href="/wiki/Little_Richard" title="Little Richard">
       Little Richard
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">
       James Brown
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Wilson" title="Jackie Wilson">
       Jackie Wilson
      </a>
      ,
