      <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">
       Diana Ross
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Fred_Astaire" title="Fred Astaire">
       Fred Astaire
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-samandfred_338-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-samandfred-338">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        338
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Sammy_Davis_Jr." title="Sammy Davis Jr.">
       Sammy Davis Jr.
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-samandfred_338-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-samandfred-338">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        338
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Gene_Kelly" title="Gene Kelly">
       Gene Kelly
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339">
       <a href="#cite_note-339">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        339
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/David_Ruffin" title="David Ruffin">
       David Ruffin
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
       <a href="#cite_note-340">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        340
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/The_Isley_Brothers" title="The Isley Brothers">
       the Isley Brothers
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">
       Bee Gees
      </a>
      , and the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/West_Side_Story" title="West Side Story">
        West Side Story
       </a>
      </i>
      dancers, to whom he made a tribute in "
      <a href="/wiki/Beat_It" title="Beat It">
       Beat It
      </a>
      " and in the "Bad" video.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341">
       <a href="#cite_note-341">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        341
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to
      <a href="/wiki/David_Winters_(choreographer)" title="David Winters (choreographer)">
       David Winters
      </a>
      , who met and befriended Jackson while choreographing the 1971
      <a href="/wiki/Diana_Ross" title="Diana Ross">
       Diana Ross
      </a>
      TV special
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Diana!" title="Diana!">
        Diana!
       </a>
      </i>
      , Jackson watched
      <a href="/wiki/West_Side_Story" title="West Side Story">
       West Side Story
      </a>
      almost every week and it was his favorite film.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342">
       <a href="#cite_note-342">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        342
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
       <a href="#cite_note-343">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        343
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344">
       <a href="#cite_note-344">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        344
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      While Little Richard had a substantial influence on Jackson,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345">
       <a href="#cite_note-345">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        345
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      James Brown was Jackson's greatest inspiration. In reference to Brown, Jackson declared: "Ever since I was a small child, no more than like six years old, my mother would wake me no matter what time it was, if I was sleeping, no matter what I was doing, to watch the television to see the master at work. And when I saw him move, I was mesmerized. I had never seen a performer perform like James Brown, and right then and there I knew that was exactly what I wanted to do for the rest of my life because of James Brown."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346">
       <a href="#cite_note-346">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        346
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The young Michael Jackson owed his vocal technique in large part to Diana Ross. Not only a mother figure to him, she was often observed in rehearsal as an accomplished performer. He later expressed: "I got to know her well. She taught me so much. I used to just sit in the corner and watch the way she moved. She was art in motion. I studied the way she moved, the way she sang  just the way she was." He told her: "I want to be just like you, Diana." She said: "You just be yourself."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347">
       <a href="#cite_note-347">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        347
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      But Jackson owed part of his enduring styleespecially his use of the
      <i>
       oooh
      </i>
      interjectionto Ross. From a young age, Jackson often punctuated his verses with a sudden exclamation of
      <i>
       oooh
      </i>
      . Diana Ross had used this effect on many of the songs recorded with
      <a href="/wiki/The_Supremes" title="The Supremes">
       the Supremes
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348">
       <a href="#cite_note-348">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        348
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Musical_themes_and_genres">
       Musical themes and genres
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Unlike many artists, Jackson did not write his songs on paper. Instead he would dictate into a sound recorder, and when recording he would sing the lyrics from memory.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
       <a href="#cite_note-349">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        349
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In most of his songs, such as "
      <a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean" title="Billie Jean">
       Billie Jean
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Who_Is_It_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Who Is It (Michael Jackson song)">
       Who Is It
      </a>
      ", and "
      <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_Junkie" title="Tabloid Junkie">
       Tabloid Junkie
      </a>
      ", he would beatbox and imitate the instruments using his voice instead of playing the actual instruments, along with other sounds. Jackson noted that it is easier to sing a drum line, or sing a bass, instead of playing a drum line or a bass with an instrument. Several critics have said that Jackson's distinct voice was able to replace any instrument convincingly. Steve Huey of
      <a href="/wiki/AllMusic" title="AllMusic">
       AllMusic
      </a>
      said that, throughout his solo career, Jackson's versatility allowed him to experiment with various themes and genres.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a musician, he explored a variety of music genres, including
      <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">
       pop
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul music">
       soul
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues" title="Rhythm and blues">
       rhythm and blues
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">
       funk
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">
       rock
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">
       disco
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Post-disco" title="Post-disco">
       post-disco
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/New_jack_swing" title="New jack swing">
       new jack swing
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio2_137-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bio2-137">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        137
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMOFW_350-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMOFW-350">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        350
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Help_351-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Help-351">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        351
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
       <a href="#cite_note-352">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        352
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg">
        <img alt="Black and white photo of Jackson holding a microphone and singing." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="791" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg/220px-Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg/330px-Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg/440px-Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson1_1988.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson in 1988, in Vienna, Austria, during his
        <a href="/wiki/Bad_(tour)" title="Bad (tour)">
         Bad World Tour
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      According to Huey,
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      refined the strengths of
      <i>
       Off the Wall
      </i>
      ; the dance and rock tracks were more aggressive, while the pop tunes and ballads were softer and more soulful.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Notable tracks included the ballads "The Lady in My Life", "
      <a href="/wiki/Human_Nature_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)">
       Human Nature
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/The_Girl_Is_Mine" title="The Girl Is Mine">
       The Girl Is Mine
      </a>
      "; the funk pieces "Billie Jean" and "
      <a href="/wiki/Wanna_Be_Startin%27_Somethin%27" title="Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'">
       Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'
      </a>
      "; and the disco set "
      <a href="/wiki/Baby_Be_Mine_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Baby Be Mine (Michael Jackson song)">
       Baby Be Mine
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/P.Y.T._(Pretty_Young_Thing)" title="P.Y.T. (Pretty Young Thing)">
       P.Y.T. (Pretty Young Thing)
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMThriller_353-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMThriller-353">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        353
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
       <a href="#cite_note-354">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        354
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_355-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Thriller-355">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        355
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      With
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      , Christopher Connelly of
      <i>
       Rolling Stone
      </i>
      commented that Jackson developed his long association with the subliminal theme of
      <a href="/wiki/Paranoia" title="Paranoia">
       paranoia
      </a>
      and darker imagery.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_355-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Thriller-355">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        355
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      AllMusic's
      <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine" title="Stephen Thomas Erlewine">
       Stephen Thomas Erlewine
      </a>
      noted this is evident on the songs "Billie Jean" and "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMThriller_353-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMThriller-353">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        353
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In "Billie Jean", Jackson sings about an obsessive fan who alleges he has fathered a child of hers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'" he argues against gossip and the media.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_355-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Thriller-355">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        355
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "Beat It" decried gang violence in an homage to
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/West_Side_Story" title="West Side Story">
        West Side Story
       </a>
      </i>
      , and was Jackson's first successful rock cross-over piece, according to Huey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bio_36-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bio-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He also observed that the title track "
      <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(song)" title="Thriller (song)">
       Thriller
      </a>
      " began Jackson's interest with the theme of the
      <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">
       supernatural
      </a>
      , a topic he revisited in subsequent years.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1985, Jackson co-wrote the charity anthem "
      <a href="/wiki/We_Are_the_World" title="We Are the World">
       We Are the World
      </a>
      "; humanitarian themes later became a recurring theme in his lyrics and public persona.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="mbox-small" style="border:1px solid #aaa;background-color:#f9f9f9;">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <div class="center">
         <div class="floatnone">

         </div>
        </div>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em">
        <div class="haudio">

          </a>

          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">
          One of Jackson's signature pieces, "Thriller", released as a single in 1984, utilizes cinematic sound effects, horror film motifs and vocal trickery to convey a sense of danger.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G23_46-1">
           <a href="#cite_note-G23-46">
            <span>
             [
            </span>
            46
            <span>
             ]
            </span>
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <hr/>
        <div class="haudio">
         <div style="padding:4px 0">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg" title="File:Smooth Criminal by Michael Jackson.ogg">
           "Smooth Criminal"
          </a>
         </div>
         <div>
          <div class="mediaContainer" style="position:relative;display:block;width:220px">
           <audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="27.956825396825" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_1" poster="//en.wikipedia.org/static/1.26wmf13/resources/assets/file-type-icons/fileicon-ogg.png" preload="none" style="width:220px">
            <source data-bandwidth="69807" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (70 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/68/Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'>
            </source>
            Sorry, your browser either has JavaScript disabled or does not have any supported player.
            <br/>
            You can
            <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/68/Smooth_Criminal_by_Michael_Jackson.ogg">
             download the clip
            </a>
            or
            <a href="https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Extension:TimedMediaHandler/Client_download">
             download a player
            </a>
            to play the clip in your browser.
           </audio>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">
          A single from the album
          <i>
           Bad
          </i>
          , released 1988, "Smooth Criminal" features digital drum sounds, keyboard-created bass lines and other percussion elements designed to give the impression of a pulsing heart.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G24_356-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-G24-356">
            <span>
             [
            </span>
            356
            <span>
             ]
            </span>
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <hr/>
        <div class="haudio">
         <div style="padding:4px 0">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg" title="File:Michael Jackson - Black Or White.ogg">
           "Black or White"
          </a>
         </div>
         <div>
          <div class="mediaContainer" style="position:relative;display:block;width:220px">
           <audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="17.99201814059" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_2" poster="//en.wikipedia.org/static/1.26wmf13/resources/assets/file-type-icons/fileicon-ogg.png" preload="none" style="width:220px">
            <source data-bandwidth="66808" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (67 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/6f/Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'>
            </source>
            <track data-dir="ltr" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="TimedText:Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg.en.srt" kind="subtitles" label="English (en) subtitles" src="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg.en.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" srclang="en" type="text/x-srt">
            </track>
            Sorry, your browser either has JavaScript disabled or does not have any supported player.
            <br/>
            You can
            <a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/6f/Michael_Jackson_-_Black_Or_White.ogg">
             download the clip
            </a>
            or
            <a href="https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Extension:TimedMediaHandler/Client_download">
             download a player
            </a>
            to play the clip in your browser.
           </audio>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">
          The lead single from
          <i>
           Dangerous
          </i>
          , "Black or White" is a danceable rock song with hard rock elements. It was one of Jackson's most successful recordings.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357">
           <a href="#cite_note-357">
            <span>
             [
            </span>
            357
            <span>
             ]
            </span>
           </a>
          </sup>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358">
           <a href="#cite_note-358">
            <span>
             [
            </span>
            358
            <span>
             ]
            </span>
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
        <hr/>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-text" colspan="2" style="line-height:1.1em">
        <span>
         <i>
          Problems playing these files? See
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
           media help
          </a>
          .
         </i>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      In
      <i>
       Bad
      </i>
      , Jackson's concept of the predatory lover can be seen on the rock song "
      <a href="/wiki/Dirty_Diana" title="Dirty Diana">
       Dirty Diana
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359">
       <a href="#cite_note-359">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        359
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The lead single "
      <a href="/wiki/I_Just_Can%27t_Stop_Loving_You" title="I Just Can't Stop Loving You">
       I Just Can't Stop Loving You
      </a>
      " is a traditional love ballad, while "
      <a href="/wiki/Man_in_the_Mirror" title="Man in the Mirror">
       Man in the Mirror
      </a>
      " is an anthemic ballad of confession and resolution. "
      <a href="/wiki/Smooth_Criminal" title="Smooth Criminal">
       Smooth Criminal
      </a>
      " was an evocation of bloody assault, rape and likely murder.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TIME2_117-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TIME2-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      AllMusic's
      <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine" title="Stephen Thomas Erlewine">
       Stephen Thomas Erlewine
      </a>
      states that
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      presents Jackson as a very paradoxical individual.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dangerous_360-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dangerous-360">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        360
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He comments the album is more diverse than his previous
      <i>
       Bad
      </i>
      , as it appeals to an urban audience while also attracting the middle class with anthems like "
      <a href="/wiki/Heal_the_World" title="Heal the World">
       Heal the World
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dangerous_360-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dangerous-360">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        360
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first half of the record is dedicated to new jack swing, including songs like "
      <a href="/wiki/Jam_(song)" title="Jam (song)">
       Jam
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Remember_the_Time" title="Remember the Time">
       Remember the Time
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The album is Jackson's first where social ills become a primary theme; "Why You Wanna Trip on Me", for example, protests against world hunger, AIDS, homelessness and drugs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      contains sexually charged efforts such as the multifaceted love song, "
      <a href="/wiki/In_the_Closet" title="In the Closet">
       In the Closet
      </a>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The title track continues the theme of the predatory lover and compulsive desire.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The second half includes introspective, pop-gospel anthems such as "
      <a href="/wiki/Will_You_Be_There" title="Will You Be There">
       Will You Be There
      </a>
      ", "Heal the World" and "Keep the Faith"; these songs show Jackson opening up about various personal struggles and worries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the ballad "
      <a href="/wiki/Gone_Too_Soon" title="Gone Too Soon">
       Gone Too Soon
      </a>
      ", Jackson gives tribute to his friend
      <a href="/wiki/Ryan_White" title="Ryan White">
       Ryan White
      </a>
      and the plight of those with AIDS.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
       <a href="#cite_note-362">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        362
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <i>
       HIStory
      </i>
      creates an atmosphere of paranoia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMHIStory_363-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMHIStory-363">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        363
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its content focuses on the hardships and public struggles Jackson went through just prior to its production. In the new jack swing-funk-rock efforts "
      <a href="/wiki/Scream/Childhood" title="Scream/Childhood">
       Scream
      </a>
      " and "Tabloid Junkie", along with the R&amp;B ballad "
      <a href="/wiki/You_Are_Not_Alone" title="You Are Not Alone">
       You Are Not Alone
      </a>
      ", Jackson retaliates against the injustice and isolation he feels, and directs much of his anger at the media.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSHIStory_364-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RSHIStory-364">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        364
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the introspective ballad "
      <a href="/wiki/Stranger_in_Moscow" title="Stranger in Moscow">
       Stranger in Moscow
      </a>
      ", Jackson laments over his "fall from grace", while songs like "
      <a href="/wiki/Earth_Song" title="Earth Song">
       Earth Song
      </a>
      ", "
      <a href="/wiki/Scream/Childhood" title="Scream/Childhood">
       Childhood
      </a>
      ", "Little Susie" and "Smile" are all operatic pop pieces.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMHIStory_363-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMHIStory-363">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        363
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSHIStory_364-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RSHIStory-364">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        364
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the track "
      <a href="/wiki/D.S._(song)" title="D.S. (song)">
       D.S.
      </a>
      ", Jackson launched a verbal attack against
      <a href="/wiki/Thomas_W._Sneddon,_Jr." title="Thomas W. Sneddon, Jr.">
       Tom Sneddon
      </a>
      . He describes Sneddon as an antisocial, white supremacist who wanted to "get my ass, dead or alive". Of the song, Sneddon said, "I have notshall we saydone him the honor of listening to it, but I've been told that it ends with the sound of a gunshot".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365">
       <a href="#cite_note-365">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        365
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      found Jackson working heavily with producer Rodney Jerkins.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It is a record made up of urban soul like "
      <a href="/wiki/Cry_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Cry (Michael Jackson song)">
       Cry
      </a>
      " and "The Lost Children", ballads such as "
      <a href="/wiki/Speechless_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Speechless (Michael Jackson song)">
       Speechless
      </a>
      ", "Break of Dawn", and "
      <a href="/wiki/Butterflies_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Butterflies (Michael Jackson song)">
       Butterflies
      </a>
      " and mixes
      <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">
       hip hop
      </a>
      , pop, and R&amp;B in "2000 Watts", "Heartbreaker" and "Invincible".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366">
       <a href="#cite_note-366">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        366
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367">
       <a href="#cite_note-367">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        367
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Vocal_style">
       Vocal style
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Jackson sang from childhood, and over time his voice and vocal style changed noticeably. Between 1971 and 1975, Jackson's voice descended from boy soprano to high tenor.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368">
       <a href="#cite_note-368">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        368
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His vocal range as an adult was F2-E6. Jackson first used a technique called the "
      <a href="/wiki/Vocal_hiccup" title="Vocal hiccup">
       vocal hiccup
      </a>
      " in 1973, starting with the song "It's Too Late to Change the Time" from
      <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">
       the Jackson 5
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/G.I.T.:_Get_It_Together" title="G.I.T.: Get It Together">
        G.I.T.: Get It Together
       </a>
      </i>
      album.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369">
       <a href="#cite_note-369">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        369
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson did not use the hiccup techniquesomewhat like a gulping for air or gaspingfully until the recording of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Off_the_Wall_(album)" title="Off the Wall (album)">
        Off the Wall
       </a>
      </i>
      : it can be seen in full force in the "
      <a href="/wiki/Shake_Your_Body_(Down_to_the_Ground)" title="Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)">
       Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)
      </a>
      " promotional video.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G22_42-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G22-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the arrival of
      <i>
       Off the Wall
      </i>
      in the late 1970s, Jackson's abilities as a vocalist were well regarded. At the time,
      <i>
       Rolling Stone
      </i>
      compared his vocals to the "breathless, dreamy stutter" of Stevie Wonder. Their analysis was also that "Jackson's feathery-timbred tenor is extraordinarily beautiful. It slides smoothly into a startling
      <a href="/wiki/Falsetto" title="Falsetto">
       falsetto
      </a>
      that's used very daringly".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMOFW_350-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AMOFW-350">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        350
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370">
       <a href="#cite_note-370">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        370
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      1982 saw the release of
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      , and
      <i>
       Rolling Stone
      </i>
      was of the opinion that Jackson was then singing in a "fully adult voice" that was "tinged by sadness".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thriller_355-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Thriller-355">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        355
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A distinctive deliberate mispronunciation of "come on", used frequently by Jackson, occasionally spelled "c'mon", "cha'mone", or "shamone", is also a staple in impressions and caricatures of him.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371">
       <a href="#cite_note-371">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        371
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The turn of the 1990s saw the release of the introspective album
      <i>
       Dangerous
      </i>
      .
      <i>
       The New York Times
      </i>
      noted that on some tracks, "he gulps for breath, his voice quivers with anxiety or drops to a desperate whisper, hissing through clenched teeth" and he had a "wretched tone".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      When singing of brotherhood or self-esteem the musician would return to "smooth" vocals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Dangerous_361-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_Dangerous-361">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        361
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      When commenting on
      <i>
       Invincible
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       Rolling Stone
      </i>
      were of the opinion thatat the age of 43Jackson still performed "exquisitely voiced rhythm tracks and vibrating vocal harmonies".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372">
       <a href="#cite_note-372">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        372
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Nelson George summed up Jackson's vocals by stating "The grace, the aggression, the growling, the natural boyishness, the falsetto, the smoothnessthat combination of elements mark him as a major vocalist".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G24_356-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G24-356">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        356
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Very concerned about a transparent rendition of this identity, the sound engineer
      <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Swedien" title="Bruce Swedien">
       Bruce Swedien
      </a>
      opted for some technical approaches and studio strategies aiming at keeping as truly as possible the singer's intimate and natural expressions: mikes, analogic recordings, special techniques elaborated to design vocal prisms, creation of natural acoustic spaces, conversion of stereophonic fields in tri-dimensional sound spaces playing with early reflections, plywood, Monstercable or Tubetraps.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373">
       <a href="#cite_note-373">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        373
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Music_videos_and_choreography">
       Music videos and choreography
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Jackson has also been referred to as the King of Music Videos.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374">
       <a href="#cite_note-374">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        374
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Steve Huey of AllMusic observed how Jackson transformed the music video into an art form and a promotional tool through complex story lines, dance routines, special effects and famous cameo appearances, simultaneously breaking down racial barriers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Before
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      , Jackson struggled to receive coverage on MTV, allegedly because he was African American.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375">
       <a href="#cite_note-375">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        375
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Pressure from CBS Records persuaded MTV to start showing "Billie Jean" and later "Beat It", leading to a lengthy partnership with Jackson, also helping other black music artists gain recognition.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Video_376-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Video-376">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        376
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      MTV employees deny any racism in their coverage, or pressure to change their stance. MTV maintains that they played rock music, regardless of race.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377">
       <a href="#cite_note-377">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        377
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The popularity of his videos on MTV helped to put the relatively young channel "on the map"; MTV's focus shifted in favor of pop and R&amp;B.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Video_376-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Video-376">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        376
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378">
       <a href="#cite_note-378">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        378
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His performance on
      <i>
       Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever
      </i>
      changed the scope of live stage show; "That Jackson lip-synced 'Billie Jean' is, in itself, not extraordinary, but the fact that it did not change the impact of the performance is extraordinary; whether the performance was live or lip-synced made no difference to the audience" thus creating an era in which artists re-create the spectacle of music video imagery on stage.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379">
       <a href="#cite_note-379">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        379
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Short films like
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Thriller_(music_video)" title="Michael Jackson's Thriller (music video)">
        Thriller
       </a>
      </i>
      largely remained unique to Jackson, while the group dance sequence in "Beat It" has frequently been imitated.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380">
       <a href="#cite_note-380">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        380
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The choreography in
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      has become a part of global pop culture, replicated everywhere from
      <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">
       Indian films
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Thriller_(viral_video)" title="Thriller (viral video)">
       prisons in the Philippines
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381">
       <a href="#cite_note-381">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        381
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      short film marked an increase in scale for music videos, and has been named the most successful music video ever by the
      <i>
       Guinness World Records
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Records_140-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-World_Records-140">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        140
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the 19-minute music video for "
      <a href="/wiki/Bad_(Michael_Jackson_song)" title="Bad (Michael Jackson song)">
       Bad
      </a>
      "directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Martin_Scorsese" title="Martin Scorsese">
       Martin Scorsese
      </a>
      Jackson began using sexual imagery and choreography not previously seen in his work. He occasionally grabbed or touched his chest, torso and crotch. When asked by Oprah in the 1993 interview about why he grabbed his crotch, he replied, "I think it happens subliminally" and he described it as something that was not planned, but rather, as something that was compelled by the music. "Bad" garnered a mixed reception from both fans and critics;
      <i>
       Time
      </i>
      magazine described it as "infamous". The video also featured
      <a href="/wiki/Wesley_Snipes" title="Wesley Snipes">
       Wesley Snipes
      </a>
      ; in the future Jackson's videos would often feature famous cameo roles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T3703_109-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-T3703-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382">
       <a href="#cite_note-382">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        382
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      For the "
      <a href="/wiki/Smooth_Criminal" title="Smooth Criminal">
       Smooth Criminal
      </a>
      " video, Jackson experimented with an anti-gravity lean where the performer leans forward at a 45 degree angle, beyond the performer's center of gravity. To accomplish this move live, Jackson and designers developed a special shoe that locks the performer's feet to the stage, allowing them to lean forward. They were granted
      <span>
       <a class="external text" href="http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?patentnumber=5255452" rel="nofollow">
        U.S. Patent 5,255,452
       </a>
      </span>
      for the device.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383">
       <a href="#cite_note-383">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        383
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although the music video for "
      <a href="/wiki/Leave_Me_Alone" title="Leave Me Alone">
       Leave Me Alone
      </a>
      " was not officially released in the US, in 1989 it was nominated for three
      <i>
       Billboard
      </i>
      Music Video Awards;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384">
       <a href="#cite_note-384">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        384
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      the same year it won a Golden Lion Award for the quality of the special effects used in its production. In 1990, "Leave Me Alone" won a Grammy for
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Music_Video" title="Grammy Award for Best Music Video">
       Best Music Video, Short Form
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G434_135-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-G434-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      He received the
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson_Video_Vanguard_Award" title="Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award">
       MTV Video Vanguard Award
      </a>
      in 1988 and the MTV Video Vanguard Artist of the Decade Award in 1990 to celebrate his accomplishments in the art form in the 1980s; in 1991 the first award was renamed in his honor.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "
      <a href="/wiki/Black_or_White" title="Black or White">
       Black or White
      </a>
      " was accompanied by a controversial music video, which, on November 14, 1991, simultaneously premiered in 27 countries with an estimated audience of 500 million people, the largest viewing ever for a music video at that time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Achievements_150-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-Achievements-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It featured scenes construed as having a sexual nature as well as depictions of violence. The offending scenes in the final half of the 14-minute version were edited out to prevent the video from being banned, and Jackson apologized.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385">
       <a href="#cite_note-385">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        385
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Along with Jackson, it featured
      <a href="/wiki/Macaulay_Culkin" title="Macaulay Culkin">
       Macaulay Culkin
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Peggy_Lipton" title="Peggy Lipton">
       Peggy Lipton
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/George_Wendt" title="George Wendt">
       George Wendt
      </a>
      . It helped usher in
      <a href="/wiki/Morphing" title="Morphing">
       morphing
      </a>
      as an important technology in music videos.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386">
       <a href="#cite_note-386">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        386
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      "
      <a href="/wiki/Remember_the_Time" title="Remember the Time">
       Remember the Time
      </a>
      " was an elaborate production, and became one of his longest videos at over nine minutes. Set in
      <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">
       ancient Egypt
      </a>
      , it featured groundbreaking
      <a href="/wiki/Visual_effects" title="Visual effects">
       visual effects
      </a>
      and appearances by
      <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Murphy" title="Eddie Murphy">
       Eddie Murphy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Iman_(model)" title="Iman (model)">
       Iman
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Magic_Johnson" title="Magic Johnson">
       Magic Johnson
      </a>
      , along with a distinct complex dance routine.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387">
       <a href="#cite_note-387">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        387
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The video for "
      <a href="/wiki/In_the_Closet" title="In the Closet">
       In the Closet
      </a>
      " was Jackson's most sexually provocative piece. It featured supermodel
      <a href="/wiki/Naomi_Campbell" title="Naomi Campbell">
       Naomi Campbell
      </a>
      in a courtship dance with Jackson. The video was banned in South Africa because of its imagery.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G456_151-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-G456-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The music video for "
      <a href="/wiki/Scream/Childhood" title="Scream/Childhood">
       Scream
      </a>
      ", directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Mark_Romanek" title="Mark Romanek">
       Mark Romanek
      </a>
      and production designer Tom Foden, is one of Jackson's most critically acclaimed. In 1995, it gained eleven
      <a href="/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award" title="MTV Video Music Award">
       MTV Video Music Award Nominations
      </a>
      more than any other music videoand won "Best Dance Video", "Best Choreography", and "Best Art Direction".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388">
       <a href="#cite_note-388">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        388
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The song and its accompanying video are a response to the backlash Jackson received from the media after being accused of child molestation in 1993.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389">
       <a href="#cite_note-389">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        389
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A year later, it won a Grammy for Best Music Video, Short Form; shortly afterwards
      <i>
       Guinness World Records
      </i>
      listed it as the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_music_videos" title="List of most expensive music videos">
       most expensive music video ever made
      </a>
      at a cost of $7 million.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390">
       <a href="#cite_note-390">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        390
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      "
      <a href="/wiki/Earth_Song" title="Earth Song">
       Earth Song
      </a>
      " was accompanied by an expensive and well-received music video that gained a Grammy nomination for Best Music Video, Short Form in 1997. The video had an environmental theme, showing images of animal cruelty, deforestation, pollution and war. Using special effects, time is reversed so that life returns, wars end, and the forests re-grow.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391">
       <a href="#cite_note-391">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        391
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Released in 1997 and premiering at the 1996
      <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">
       Cannes Film Festival
      </a>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson%27s_Ghosts" title="Michael Jackson's Ghosts">
        Michael Jackson's Ghosts
       </a>
      </i>
      was a short film written by Jackson and
      <a href="/wiki/Stephen_King" title="Stephen King">
       Stephen King
      </a>
      and directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Winston" title="Stan Winston">
       Stan Winston
      </a>
      . The video for
      <i>
       Ghosts
      </i>
      is over 38 minutes long and holds the
      <i>
       Guinness World Record
      </i>
      as the world's longest music video.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G4850_198-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-G4850-198">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        198
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-T6101_207-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-T6101-207">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        207
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392">
       <a href="#cite_note-392">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        392
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393">
       <a href="#cite_note-393">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        393
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy_and_influence">
       Legacy and influence
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Records_and_achievements_of_Michael_Jackson" title="Records and achievements of Michael Jackson">
       Records and achievements of Michael Jackson
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_artists_influenced_by_Michael_Jackson" title="List of artists influenced by Michael Jackson">
       List of artists influenced by Michael Jackson
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg">
        <img alt='Pink star with a gold colored rim and the writing "Michael Jackson" in its center. The star is indented into the ground and is surrounded by a marble-colored floor.' class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1557" data-file-width="1640" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg/170px-1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg/255px-1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg/340px-1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1993_walk_of_fame_michael_jackson.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Jackson's star on the
        <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">
         Hollywood Walk of Fame
        </a>
        , set in 1984.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The media has commonly referred to Jackson as the "
      <a href="/wiki/Honorific_nicknames_in_popular_music" title="Honorific nicknames in popular music">
       King of Pop
      </a>
      " because, throughout his career, he transformed the art of music videos and paved the way for modern pop music.
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">
        The Daily Telegraph
       </a>
      </i>
      writer
      <a href="/wiki/Tom_Utley" title="Tom Utley">
       Tom Utley
      </a>
      described Jackson in 2003 as "extremely important" and a "genius".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394">
       <a href="#cite_note-394">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        394
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      For much of his career, he had an "unparalleled" level of worldwide influence over the younger generation through his musical and humanitarian contributions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ADL_200-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ADL-200">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        200
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Jackson's music and videos, such as
      <i>
       Thriller
      </i>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/MTV#Breaking_the_color_barrier" title="MTV">
       fostered racial diversity
      </a>
      in MTV's roster, helped to put the relatively new channel into public awareness, and steered the channel's focus from rock to pop music and R&amp;B, shaping the channel into a form that proved enduring. Jackson's work continues to influence numerous artists of various music genres. BET described Jackson "as quite simply the greatest entertainer of all time" and someone who "revolutionized the music video and brought dances like the moonwalk to the world. Jackson's sound, style, movement and legacy continues to inspire artists of all genres."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395">
       <a href="#cite_note-395">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        395
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      AllMusic's Steve Huey describes Jackson as "an unstoppable juggernaut, possessed of all the skills to dominate the charts seemingly at will: an instantly identifiable voice, eye-popping dance moves, stunning musical versatility and loads of sheer star power".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_3-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-allmusic-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the mid-1980s,
      <i>
       Time
      </i>
      magazine's pop music critic,
      <a href="/wiki/Jay_Cocks" title="Jay Cocks">
       Jay Cocks
      </a>
      , noted "Jackson is the biggest thing since
      <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">
       the Beatles
      </a>
      . He is the hottest single phenomenon since
      <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">
       Elvis Presley
      </a>
      . He just may be the most popular black singer ever".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TIME_71-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-TIME-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1990,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Vanity_Fair_(magazine)" title="Vanity Fair (magazine)">
        Vanity Fair
       </a>
      </i>
      cited Jackson as the most popular artist in the history of show business.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G434_135-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-G434-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2007, Jackson said, "Music has been my outlet, my gift to all of the lovers in this world. Through it, my music, I know I will live forever."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396">
       <a href="#cite_note-396">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        396
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Shortly after Jackson's death, on June 25, 2009, MTV briefly returned to its original music video format to celebrate and pay tribute to his work.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397">
       <a href="#cite_note-397">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        397
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The channel aired many hours of Jackson's music videos, accompanied by live news specials featuring reactions from MTV personalities and other celebrities. The temporary shift in MTV's programming culminated the following week in the channel's live coverage of Jackson's memorial service.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398">
       <a href="#cite_note-398">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        398
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the memorial service on July 7, 2009, founder of
      <a href="/wiki/Motown" title="Motown">
       Motown
      </a>
      Berry Gordy proclaimed Jackson as "the greatest entertainer that ever lived".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399">
       <a href="#cite_note-399">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        399
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400">
       <a href="#cite_note-400">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        400
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401">
       <a href="#cite_note-401">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        401
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2010, two university librarians found that Jackson's influence extended into
      <a href="/wiki/Academia" title="Academia">
       academia
      </a>
      , and has been mentioned in scholarly literature pertaining to a range of subject matter.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler_402-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Chandler-402">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        402
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403">
       <a href="#cite_note-403">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        403
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The two researchers combed through various scholars' writings, and compiled an
      <a href="/wiki/Annotated_bibliography" title="Annotated bibliography">
       annotated bibliography
      </a>
      of those writings. The bibliography located references to Jackson in research reports concerning music, popular culture, chemistry and an array of other topics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chandler_402-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Chandler-402">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        402
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404">
       <a href="#cite_note-404">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        404
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Honors_and_awards">
       Honors and awards
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Michael_Jackson" title="List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson">
       List of awards and nominations received by Michael Jackson
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thriller_platinum_record,_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1777" data-file-width="1435" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG/170px-Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG/255px-Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG/340px-Thriller_platinum_record%2C_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thriller_platinum_record,_Hard_Rock_Cafe_Hollywood.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <i>
         Thriller
        </i>
        platinum record on display at the
        <a href="/wiki/Hard_Rock_Cafe" title="Hard Rock Cafe">
         Hard Rock Cafe
        </a>
        , Hollywood in Universal City, California.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Michael Jackson was inducted onto the
      <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">
       Hollywood Walk of Fame
      </a>
      in 1980 as member of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Jacksons" title="The Jacksons">
       the Jacksons
      </a>
      and in 1984 as solo artist. Throughout his career he received numerous honors and awards, including the
      <a href="/wiki/World_Music_Awards" title="World Music Awards">
       World Music Awards
      </a>
      ' Best-Selling Pop Male Artist of the Millennium, the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Award" title="American Music Award">
       American Music Award
      </a>
      's Artist of the Century Award and the
      <a href="/wiki/Bambi_Award" title="Bambi Award">
       Bambi
      </a>
      Pop Artist of the Millennium Award.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G503_213-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G503-213">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        213
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405">
       <a href="#cite_note-405">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        405
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He was a double-inductee of the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame_inductees#Performers" title="List of Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees">
       Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
      </a>
      , once as a member of The Jackson 5 in 1997 and later as a solo artist in 2001. Jackson was also inducted in several other halls of fame, including
      <a href="/wiki/Vocal_Group_Hall_of_Fame#Vocal_Group_Hall_of_Fame_Inductees" title="Vocal Group Hall of Fame">
       Vocal Group Hall of Fame
      </a>
      (as a
      <a href="/wiki/The_Jackson_5" title="The Jackson 5">
       Jackson 5
      </a>
      member) in 1999 and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inductees_of_the_Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame#J" title="Inductees of the Songwriters Hall of Fame">
       Songwriters Hall of Fame
      </a>
      in 2002.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G503_213-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G503-213">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        213
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2010, Jackson was inducted into the Dance Hall of Fame as the first (and currently only) dancer from the world of pop and rock 'n' roll.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406">
       <a href="#cite_note-406">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        406
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2014, Jackson was inducted into the second class of inductees to the
      <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_Blues_Music_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame">
       Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame
      </a>
      ; his father Joe Jackson accepted on his behalf.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407">
       <a href="#cite_note-407">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        407
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      His awards include many
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">
        Guinness World Records
       </a>
      </i>
      (eight in 2006 alone),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408">
       <a href="#cite_note-408">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        408
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      13
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">
       Grammy Awards
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409">
       <a href="#cite_note-409">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        409
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      (as well as the
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Legend_Award" title="Grammy Legend Award">
       Grammy Legend Award
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410">
       <a href="#cite_note-410">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        410
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award" title="Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award">
       Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award
      </a>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411">
       <a href="#cite_note-411">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        411
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      26
      <a href="/wiki/American_Music_Award" title="American Music Award">
       American Music Awards
      </a>
      (including the "Artist of the Century" and "Artist of the 1980s"),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTV_211-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MTV-211">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        211
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412">
       <a href="#cite_note-412">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        412
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      more than any artist13
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_artists_who_reached_number_one_in_the_United_States#J" title="List of artists who reached number one in the United States">
       number-one singles in the US
      </a>
      in his solo careermore than any other male artist in the Hot 100 era
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413">
       <a href="#cite_note-413">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        413
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and estimated sales of over 400 million records worldwide,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414">
       <a href="#cite_note-414">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        414
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415">
       <a href="#cite_note-415">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        415
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="ref_Note_1">
       <a href="#endnote_Note_1">
        [Note 1]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which makes him one of the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">
       best-selling artists of all time
      </a>
      . On December 29, 2009, the American Film Institute recognized Jackson's death as a "moment of significance" saying, "Michael Jackson's sudden death in June at age 50 was notable for the worldwide outpouring of grief and the unprecedented global eulogy of his posthumous concert rehearsal movie
      <i>
       This Is It
      </i>
      ."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416">
       <a href="#cite_note-416">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        416
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Michael Jackson also received a Doctor of Humane Letters Degree from the United Negro College Fund
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417">
       <a href="#cite_note-417">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        417
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and also an Honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters from Fisk University.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418">
       <a href="#cite_note-418">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        418
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Earnings_and_wealth">
       Earnings and wealth
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      It is estimated that Michael Jackson earned about $750 million in his lifetime.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419">
       <a href="#cite_note-419">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        419
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sales of his recordings through Sony's music unit earned him an estimated $300 million in royalties. He may have also earned an additional $400 million from concerts, music publishing (including his share of the Beatles catalog) endorsements, merchandising and music videos. Estimating how much of these earnings Jackson was able to personally pocket is difficult because one has to account for taxes, recording costs and production costs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420">
       <a href="#cite_note-420">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        420
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There have also been several detailed estimates of Jackson's net worth and these range from negative $285 million to positive $350 million.
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable">
      <caption>
       Michael Jackson's estimated net-worth over the years
      </caption>
      <tr>
       <th>
        Year
       </th>
       <th>
        Assets
       </th>
       <th>
        Debt
       </th>
       <th>
        Net worth
       </th>
       <th>
        Source
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        2002
       </td>
       <td>
        $130 million
       </td>
       <td>
        $415 million
       </td>
       <td>
        -$285 million
       </td>
       <td>
        Forensic accountant in 2005 recalling Jackson's 2002 balance sheet under oath
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421">
         <a href="#cite_note-421">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          421
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        2003
       </td>
       <td>
        $550 million ($100 million in properties including Neverland ranch; Encino and Las Vegas homes and other properties and $450 million in music holdings including 50% stake in Sony ATV and other music publishing)
       </td>
       <td>
        $200 million
       </td>
       <td>
        $350 million
       </td>
       <td>
        <i>
         Forbes
        </i>
        , November 21, 2003
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422">
         <a href="#cite_note-422">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          422
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        2007
       </td>
       <td>
        $567.6 million (includes 50% share of the Sony/ATV catalog valued at $390.6 million, Neverland valued at $33 million, cars, antiques, collectibles and other property valued at $20 million, and $668,215 in cash)
       </td>
       <td>
        $331 million
       </td>
       <td>
        $236 million
       </td>
       <td>
        Michael Jackson's March 2007 statement of financial condition prepared by Washington-based accounting firm Thompson, Cobb, Bazilio &amp; Associates; described by CBS News as the clearest account yet of Jackson's finances.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423">
         <a href="#cite_note-423">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          423
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._Federal_estate_tax_problems">
       U.S. Federal estate tax problems
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      On July 26, 2013, the executors of the Estate of Michael Jackson filed a petition in the
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Tax_Court" title="United States Tax Court">
       United States Tax Court
      </a>
      as a result of a dispute with the
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Service" title="Internal Revenue Service">
       Internal Revenue Service
      </a>
      (IRS) over
      <a href="/wiki/Estate_tax_in_the_United_States" title="Estate tax in the United States">
       U.S. federal estate taxes
      </a>
      imposed on the value of Jackson's Estate at the time of his death. The executors of the Estate claim that the Estate was worth about $7 million. The IRS asserts that the Estate was worth over $1.1 billion, and that over $700 million in federal estate taxes (including penalties) are due.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gottlieb_333-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Gottlieb-333">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        333
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424">
       <a href="#cite_note-424">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        424
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      <b>
       Note 1
       <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Note_1">
        <b>
         <a href="#ref_Note_1">
          ^
         </a>
        </b>
       </span>
      </b>
     </p>
     <div class="refbegin" style="">
      <ul>
       <li>
        According to
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">
          The Wall Street Journal
         </a>
        </i>
        and diverse news sites, the 750 million units sold by Michael Jackson is an inflated figure that was initially claimed by
        <a href="/wiki/Raymone_Bain" title="Raymone Bain">
         Raymone Bain
        </a>
        (2006),
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425">
         <a href="#cite_note-425">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          425
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426">
         <a href="#cite_note-426">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          426
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
        who was the singer's publicist at that time, without any factual evidence and probably in an effort to promote album sales.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427">
         <a href="#cite_note-427">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          427
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428">
         <a href="#cite_note-428">
          <span>
           [
          </span>
          428
          <span>
           ]
          </span>
         </a>
        </sup>
        From 2006 until present time, several sources such as
        <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">
         MTV
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Reuters" title="Reuters">
         Reuters
        </a>
        , and
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Billboard_(magazine)" title="Billboard (magazine)">
          Billboard
         </a>
        </i>
        have claimed that Michael Jackson has sold 750 million units, however, Adrian Strain, a representative from the
        <a href="/wiki/International_Federation_of_the_Phonographic_Industry" title="International Federation of the Phonographic Industry">
         International Federation of the Phonographic Industry
        </a>
        (IFPI) has said that this figure is unreal.
       </li>
      </ul>
     </div>

          </a>
          on September 15, 2008.
